According to the Commission ORG external policy can succeed provided everyone knows exactly who is in charge! So who is this then? The Commission as a whole its President perhaps the Council ORG ? It is high time that institutions restricted their scope to actual cross border issues and stopped decking out the European NORP cart with powers which they are taking away from national authorities. This raises the question as to what these standards and values are based on. I am convinced that the Bible WORK_OF_ART God s word is the only pure source of proper standards and real values. In the tradition of our continent this realisation is an important one which merits recognition. Its borders are set not by how may countries want to join but by how many countries it can accommodate. SPEAKER ID 36 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL ORG NAME Maes Madam ORG President Mr President of the Commission Commissioners your inspiring speech Mr Prodi has quite won me over. This is a place where we share the same values and where each and one of us also have our own task and responsibility. This is probably linked to the standards mentioned by Mr Van Dam PRODUCT namely subsidiarity. It is necessary to have a clear division of responsibility among all levels of authority and to be partners rather than competitors when it comes to policy. It is also necessary to exercise authority as closely as possible to the citizens where it can be exercised with due transparency and can be monitored by the citizens themselves. These are contained in an extremely general document in which all the problems have been glossed over to prevent any conflict. P So in the first ORDINAL part on the new forms of European NORP governance the words federalism and superstate are not mentioned at all. Yet these are the main themes in any discussion of strong European NORP institutions in which only day to day tasks of execution are decentralised and a collective vision is promoted within an indistinct whole. In this scenario the governments and national parliaments are merged with the regional and even local authorities and with the civil society all of which are described with no form of hierarchy as integral elements of European NORP governance . P These ambiguities mask many misunderstandings primarily about our values. It is not enough to claim to adhere to democracy in order to be a democrat NORP . It must clearly be accepted that the people should be free to make their decisions at the level which best combines the objective conditions of an immediate fair and transparent democratic debate namely at national level in the main. P Yet the whole of the Commission ORG communication is based on the opposite theory. In this theory on the pretext of ensuring the best protection for peoples their margin of independent choice should be increasingly limited by new regulations new policies or new restrictive legal structures such as the draft Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART . This Charter is really misnamed because it will actually reduce these rights. P In the Union for a Europe of Nations Group our principles are rather different. Clearly we want to defend the countries of Europe LOC but we also want to respect the autonomy of nations. This is not impossible. We must move away from the outmoded federalist schemes promoted by those whose every idea on European NORP matters comes from the Memoires of Jean Monnet PERSON . Instead we must open the European NORP institutions to the modern world by creating a flexible dynamic which respects nations. P This is the keynote idea on the new governance which we would have liked to have seen in your communication Mr Prodi but which is unfortunately not there. I would merely ask when this is likely to take effect. SPEAKER ID 42 CARDINAL NAME Grosset te Madam President Mr Prodi we are pleased about the overall intention of the objectives announced which are in line with the challenges which Europe LOC must overcome. I note that you consider the fall of the Berlin GPE wall to be the crucial factor of the end of the century DATE . This event must underpin enlargement. Rather than using the word enlargement I want to talk of reunification which has much greater political significance. P Your idea is to concentrate your activities on the core tasks. This is one of the goals of your reform. In essence this means applying the principle of subsidiarity. Precise application of this principle can only reinforce the actions taken and give our citizens a clear view of each level of competence. However saying is one thing and doing is another! You must therefore fight against the tendency of all institutions to try and increase their powers. I will therefore judge you on your deeds. In the meantime I approve and encourage this clearly expressed desire in your communication. P However I must make two CARDINAL essential points. These concern the simplification and application of Community ORG law. In 1998 123 DATE referrals were made to the Court of Justice ORG for non application or non transposition and 25 CARDINAL of environmental directives were not applied or transposed. Recent events have shown us that these regulations are essential. Community law must not go unapplied because it is too complex or too pedantic. The Union must not make this mistake and I therefore regret the fact that your communication does not go into more detail on this. P You are being realistic when you say that the welfare state can no longer provide adequate responses to the problems facing us including unemployment. Nevertheless I regret that a clear alternative has not been proposed. The emphasis should have been placed on the rejection of any policy of handouts and instead on the development of initiative and responsibility. You have not highlighted the ageing of our population which will fundamentally alter the structure of our society not only economically but also in terms of public health. This is a silent revolution and in this respect I expected more from your communication. Finally you do highlight European NORP research as being at the heart of our future. Yet you do not indicate the resources you intend to implement to achieve this. Also ethical principles are at the heart of this research but your communication says nothing about these. If you want to better inform the people you should start by strengthening liaison with this House ORG as we are the representatives of the citizens. P In the two CARDINAL documents strong emphasis is placed on the need to define new forms of European NORP governance and to this end to introduce a new agenda for the Commission establishing more stringent priorities in the pursuit of the goal of full employment through more efficient coordination of the economic and social policies of the States GPE and primarily allow me to stress this of the nations that have joined the monetary union and which must be enabled to become the first ORDINAL example of closer cooperation. P To this end I shall confine myself to stressing out of all the choices available the importance of three CARDINAL priority decisions which should in the drawing up of action programmes for the government of the Union be the basis for both the Commission s agenda and the actions of the European Union ORG in the coming months DATE . P Firstly ORDINAL the promotion of and participation in the drafting of joint plans for the creation of an integrated services network in the transport and energy sectors with the backing of the European Investment Bank ORG . P Secondly ORDINAL the approval of investments where the parameters are binding when drawing up action programmes on employment to be made in individual countries via Community projects in the priority sectors of research innovation and training. I feel that these parameters particularly those of a qualitative nature resulting from investments in continuous training refresher courses adaptability and retraining of older workers are considerably more significant and binding owing to their lasting effects over the medium term than the simple drawing up of annual DATE quantitative objectives that are always debatable regarding new employment or employment cuts. P If among other things as the programme of the Portuguese NORP Presidency stresses as well the Commission ORG could promote a new phase of social dialogue focusing on an agreed strategy of socialisation and diffusion of knowledge in other words a strategy for employability and the definition of its rules this would allow us to take a step towards having employees participate in the informed and consensual management of the restructuring and reemployment processes. P Thirdly I do not think that the decrease in the number of the working population owing to the ageing of the population is unavoidable and inevitable for the European Union ORG . This is not just because of the existence of margins which would permit an increase in the number of working women and immigration but because we need to be determined in reversing the widespread trend of early retirements from the job market and direct the coordinated reform of social welfare systems certainly not towards large reductions in future pension payments but towards the active use of people s increased life expectancy and towards a longer working life. SPEAKER ID 45 CARDINAL NAME Goebbels Madam ORG President the Commission communication is well written but sufficiently vague to allow any interpretation whatsoever. On one hand there are the words and on the other their real political meaning. P We Socialists NORP applaud the Commission for wanting to fight against social exclusion and poverty. Yet how can the gulf between political rhetoric and reality be filled? What is meant by the Commission ORG s declared objective of economic reform in the labour market? Does this mean more flexibility insecurity and fixed term contracts? Everyone knows that quality of life and full and better employment depend on sustainable economic growth. The Union is currently restricted to a policy of stability which is certainly necessary but insufficient. We Socialists NORP desperately want a European NORP pact for growth and employment. The ingredients of this policy are well known. They are the stimulation of public and private investment increased investment in research education and training and the promotion of the spirit of enterprise. In this respect the e Europe LOC initiative is to be welcomed. In the world of new technologies the main danger remains that access to information will be easier the richer you are. P The gulfs which are opening up everywhere are the main problem for our era. On one CARDINAL hand we have the exuberance of the financial markets and the explosion of wealth and on the other more widespread exclusion. We are asking workers to be flexible innovative and ever more productive yet the fruits of this productivity increasingly benefit the shareholders alone. The European Central Bank ORG is keeping very quiet about the staggering rates of return on financial assets yet it never misses an opportunity to remind us that any wage increase should remain below the rate of increase in productivity. How do we explain to workers who fall victim to the rationalisations of the worldwide Monopoly PERSON game that they must be prepared to change career several times in their working lives when the captains of industry having lost the gamble of a take over leave with compensation of EUR 30 million MONEY ? P For years DATE we have been told over and over that the economy must be liberalised. The sectors which have been liberalised are experiencing an avalanche of mergers and acquisitions leading inevitably to monopoly situations. All these stock market battles are based solely on forecast increases in profit of 15 20 or 25 CARDINAL which are unrealistic in the long term. The unfettered rise in prices of financial assets and property means that the risks are on the increase. The main danger awaiting us in the medium term is not inflation but deflation caused by the collapse of the speculative bubbles on the international financial markets. P To conclude the next five years DATE will be crucial. We need new rules to regulate globalisation and we need investment in the real economy and in people. We need the Member States and the Commission to ensure the social dimension of the market economy in a visible manner. P SPEAKER ID 46 LANGUAGE DE NAME Jarzembowski Madam President Mr President of the Commission Commissioners ORG in my view this strategy paper has two CARDINAL clear weaknesses. You have excellent Commissioners for both issues in Mrs Palacio and Mr Barnier yet still you attach too little importance to these areas. And do you know why? Just look at transport policy clearly it is crucial for this policy to be drawn up as a economically and ecologically sensible policy before the accession of other countries. P I would be grateful if the President of the Commission would listen to what I have to say although of course he has no obligation to do so. Let me give you three CARDINAL examples. First ORDINAL we need reasonable deregulation of the railway sector because we want to shift freight from the roads to the railways. That makes sense from an economic and an ecological point of view. Without deregulation we will not make any headway with a reasonable transport policy. The same applies to European NORP air traffic control. Our citizens cannot understand that we are deregulating air traffic but leaving 15 CARDINAL different sectors in the skies which are under national control which have an adverse economic impact on the airlines and which pollute the environment. You still have not finished that agenda. P Commissioner far too little is said in your paper about regional policy. Economic and social cohesion in the EU ORG is a fundamental task of this Community ORG . If we fail to complete it citizens in less favoured regions will dread enlargement. We must show them that we intend to use the next five years DATE to help them join the rich regions by promoting the less favoured regions using reasonable means. Then they too will be prepared to really support enlargement and help to achieve it. P Mr President of the Commission if we do not manage to create true solidarity between the rich and the poor regions then this Union will be all the poorer and it will not meet with the approval of the people. What your texts do not make apparent is the extent to which these major high minded objectives are compatible with the resources that the Commission ORG intends to deploy. I do not necessarily mean financial resources. The implementation of Agenda 2000 in the agricultural sector does not ultimately require more money. There must also be savings. But what we need is the analytical resources these issues require the investment of more intellectual capital. This is because it is essential to achieve two CARDINAL things the European NORP model of multifunctionality in agriculture must be secured and this must be done in a way which facilitates the liberalisation of world trade in agricultural products mainly to the benefit of developing countries. It is not easy to combine those aims. There is no obvious way. There may well be contradictions between the two CARDINAL objectives and there is nothing to show that the Commission ORG has pointed out those contradictions and how it proposes to deal with them. P As regards the other aspect of Agenda the aspect of cohesion and regional development there we do indeed have great achievements to point to but there are still less developed regions particularly island regions to which more attention should be paid. P As for fishing there is nothing in your programme to tell us that the predatory exploitation of fishing grounds which has gone as far as to wipe out entire species of fish will certainly prove fruitful in the future. Perhaps these issues should be approached with greater attention and a greater esprit de finesse. SPEAKER ID 48 CARDINAL NAME Harbour Madam ORG President I want to start by reinforcing the caution that has been expressed by many colleagues here in addressing this five year DATE plan. In setting very ambitious long term goals we must not take our eyes away from the present. That was a point made very forcibly by the leader of my group Mr Poettering in his opening address. P The Union must not take on a whole range of new tasks without the basic foundation for a successful European NORP economy being in place. That foundation is clearly the single market. How strongly is the single market established at the moment? I want to remind Mr Prodi and his colleagues who are still here of the findings of the Commission ORG s own survey among 3000 CARDINAL European NORP businesses. Nearly 40 CARDINAL of businesses in this survey are still reporting additional costs to render products or services compatible with national specifications. This is the Commission ORG s own survey. These are the classic symptoms of continued obstruction by national governments bureaucratic red tape blocking market entry. P The Commission s programme shows a disturbing complacency about the completion of the internal market. We have to keep the pressure up in all areas by removing further barriers intensifying pressure on Member States who fail to implement single market measures and of course extending into crucial new areas like financial services. Only on the strong foundation of the single market will the agenda of enlargement be successfully achieved. An enlarged Europe LOC must build on the existing strengths of the Union. The single market extending across that enlarged Union is going to be a colossal achievement. P I conclude by saying on behalf of all my Conservative NORP colleagues and we are the second ORDINAL largest national delegation in this Parliament ORG that we pledge our full support to the Commission and to Mr Prodi in achieving this historic task. SPEAKER ID 49 CARDINAL NAME Ber s Madam President Mr Prodi ladies and gentlemen at the time of our vote on your appointment we invited you to come here today DATE . The serious business is therefore now going to start as we are to vote on your programme. P From your speech I will concentrate on what you have called the new governance which you will use as a tool for reconciliation with our fellow citizens. Yet this new governance simply means how the institutions and our public authorities operate if we agree that the European Union ORG must be a public authority. P The interlinking of the EU ORG institutions the responsibilities of the Member States and the local and regional authorities is all very well. Yet is this really how we will reconcile the people and European NORP construction? Is this really how we will answer the fundamental questions which are not so much about who does what but more what are we doing together ? It is these questions which cause concern among our fellow citizens. In your speech you mentioned the challenges of globalisation and enlargement which await us. I would add to these the future of our social model. P This is why I and my group are so firmly insisting on the Charter of Fundamental Rights ORG . The reason our timetable includes the drafting of this Charter WORK_OF_ART is because we are at a key point in our history. Our Union needs to redefine the values on which it is based both within its current borders and also with a view to the imminent enlargements which we earnestly desire but not under just any conditions. P Our people expect more Europe LOC but not just any Europe LOC . They are expecting us not to fall in with globalisation but rather on the basis of our social model to be able to organise globalisation. In this respect I must say that in terms of your commitment to a political union to which we are favourable this cannot be achieved unless it is based on our social model on our originality and our capacity to better regulate the business of this world. It wishes to boost judicial assistance and cooperation and to develop an effective approach to the fight against all forms of crime . A paper such as this is no basis for a scoreboard. It has been extolled and celebrated as a huge achievement and I am all for it we need a basis for a scoreboard. We here in Parliament ORG want to hold a serious discussion about the future development in this policy area on the basis of a programme. P What we are looking for are minimum standards in asylum procedures so that refugees can be given help quickly and those who are not fleeing know where they stand. P We want instruments to prevent abuse. We want to develop a Community ORG immigration policy which takes account of the Member States capacity to absorb immigrants and we need to extend the operational powers of EUROPOL ORG for example so that specific steps can be taken to combat organised crime. P We debate these issues intensively and seriously and we should be entitled to expect likewise from the Commission even where it is merely submitting a paper. SPEAKER ID 51 LANGUAGE PT NAME Seguro Madam President Mr President of the Commission Commissioners I rise to speak on the subject of the World Trade Organisation ORG on which there is a broad convergence of views between the Commission ORG documents and the positions of the Socialist Group ORG . This is not the case in other areas as has already been pointed out. We share these views because we are in favour of world trade but we want this trade to be conducted according to common standards common rules which would regulate world trade with one aim in mind. This aim is that trade should benefit development and particularly harmonious development in which the values of citizenship do not only apply to the world s most dynamic and competitive regions. P On the other hand what does this statement tell us about principles? This regulation and these standards have brought an increased volume of trade for the World Trade Organisation ORG in other words increased wealth but when we look at how this wealth is distributed we see unfortunately that the gulf between the world s richest countries and blocks and the poorest and least developed countries continues to increase. P It is therefore quite legitimate and even imperative that we ask ourselves what purpose do the current common standards and rules serve? What good are the current way in which we negotiate and the way in which the World Trade Organisation ORG works if they cause trade to increase on the one hand but on the other they create problems and above all cause this gulf between rich and poor countries to grow? P That is why we said that we were in favour of the strategy that the Commission ORG outlined here for the Seattle GPE negotiations and for later ones. We are certainly in favour of this strategic vision but we need to be brave and ambitious. We need to be demanding and ensure that social rights environmental rights and consumer protection are incorporated into the forthcoming negotiations. Most importantly though we must have a brave and ambitious long term vision for reform not just of the WTO ORG but also of the ILO the United Nations ORG and above all of the financial institutions specifically the IMF ORDINAL and the World Bank ORG . P We must be brave and not only see some aspects of globalisation. We must be brave enough to have more of an overview of this process so that wealth does not only benefit the most highly developed blocks and countries but that there is also harmonious change and development in every region in the world. I am waiting for the Commission ORG s report on the ultra peripheral regions which the Council ORG decided should be drawn up by December 1999 DATE . P I shall finish by restating my conviction that without economic and social cohesion there will be no cohesion at all only disunity. However I was disappointed with the nature of the proposal for the establishment of a European NORP food authority in the recent White Paper ORG . In its present form what is being proposed is more like an advisory agency to the Commission rather than an independent body that would have decision and law making powers more similar to those of the US Food and Drug Administration ORG which has already established credibility in this particular field. P Furthermore future legislation must address the modus operandi of the relationship between the European NORP food authority and the authorities of national Member States for example the food safety authority in Ireland GPE . SPEAKER ID 65 LANGUAGE IT NAME Prodi . IT Madam President ladies and gentlemen thank you for this strong serious and constructive debate. It has been a calm debate with broad agreement over the basic points but also where there has been a marked reassertion of Parliament ORG s rights and of the need for cooperation and dialogue between Parliament the Commission ORG and the Council ORG . It has been a constructive debate for Europe LOC . P The document that I have presented has been described as a political manifesto with some internal contradictions. Mrs Hautala PERSON I think you were almost right in saying this because it is indeed a political manifesto. But it is not some abstract political manifesto but a manifestation of political will which we need at this delicate stage for Europe LOC . It is pointless to say that Europe LOC is in crisis if we are then unable to issue a political manifesto to discuss it to dwell on it and to draw conclusions on it together. P So the contradictions between objectives and instruments which Mrs Hautala GPE rightly pointed out reflect contradictions in the current state of affairs in Europe LOC . These are the contradictions that it is our duty to rectify and overcome. This is the importance of the political task we must tackle today DATE . I have brought them out into the open without hiding anything. I am pleased that they have been given such prominence and also sometimes been asserted so forcefully been given such importance and this is why we want to change the instruments that we use to guide our action Parliament ORG s action my action the action of all the European NORP institutions this is why we wanted an effective Intergovernmental Conference this is why Helsinki ORG signified a time of delicate change. P It has been written that we had given up the drive towards a stronger Europe LOC but then in Helsinki GPE we rekindled the flames that we had managed to keep going until then. Cast your minds back I recall this because it took place in this very Chamber to the speech given by the President of the French Republic GPE on the issues of reinforced cooperation which reopened a dialogue that appeared closed prior to this. I hope our tenacity in maintaining our positions in Helsinki GPE will be rewarded at the Intergovernmental Conference ORG which will culminate with the Nice Summit ORG . P We have been reminded by everyone not just by Mr Poettering and Mr Fiori but many speakers of globalisation and the difficulties this is causing us in our lives and policies. The Commission wants globalisation. It sees it as positive because it is providing a minimum amount of dignity for billions CARDINAL of people marginalised by the global market and because it is thanks to globalisation that a new day DATE is dawning in China GPE and India GPE for I repeat billions of people. P I hope that globalisation will continue to have this positive aspect in the future but and this is going to be one of our major commitments in the future it leads to problems in poor countries and in our countries problems that we must address. And it also leads to problems in the weakest sectors of our countries. This means examining our conscience over the practical action we must take from day to day DATE because it is clear that globalisation is causing our society to diverge increasing poverty giving more grounds for anger causing wide differences in salaries even in sectors which seem similar and we need to focus our attention on this. P Clearly when our young graduates notice differences in salaries small or large depending on the type of employment they are in and when the financial sector pays wages that are X number of times higher than someone working in research for example all of this creates problems relating to the organisation of our future society. We need to deliberate carefully over this and I am responding to Mr Trentin frankly we still have not or at least I still have not prepared a complete response in this regard. I started to respond in Lisbon GPE by attempting to reduce the marginalisation of an entire age group that is to provide all the young people of Europe LOC with new instruments for communication broadly reunite all the European NORP schools and create new opportunities to prevent geographical and social marginalisation in Europe LOC . This still does not go far enough towards controlling globalisation or at least understanding the consequences of globalisation but it is a substantial and necessary response. P In recent weeks DATE Commissioner Lamy PERSON also vigorously proposed a response at global level on behalf of the Commission to rebuild confidence in the development of the Third World that was put in such serious jeopardy at Seattle GPE and to repropose a role for the WTO ORG with a wide agenda able to address the challenge of globalisation. In Geneva the Commission ORG proposed an extraordinarily bold short term packet which complies with many of your requests. It proposed unilaterally reducing customs duties to zero CARDINAL for the 38 40 DATE poorest countries unilaterally completely and across the board it proposed reforming the WTO ORG s procedures and greater transparency it proposed giving a response to the developing countries over issues relating to the promotion of this measure. If these measures gain support over the next few days DATE the Commission as it has already announced will vigorously proceed with the relaunching of the Round for summer DATE and therefore its resumption. P We are trying to repair the damage done in Seattle GPE . This is the Commission ORG s major task and together we plan to reform the WTO ORG and establish a place for the Commission within it and the Commission will at last study the matter in great depth because it has not been done in recent years DATE . This is an initial practical response in a five year DATE programme which is not there to provide responses on individual issues but to provide these major policy lines extracts from our future action extracts where Parliament ORG s supervision is essential as is collaboration between Parliament ORG and the Commission. The synergies between the Commission Parliament ORG and the Council ORG are essential Mr Cox. P Clearly this will compel us as we have seen and as was the subject of a large part of my intervention to rethink the concept of subsidiarity. I am grateful to Mr Poettering Mr Cox and the others who mentioned this. This is the cornerstone of the programme. Too often subsidiarity has been lauded in theory but has not been understood in practice. We must give subsidiarity a material body and a political soul this is the aim of the White Paper which must put value back into Europe LOC and recommend what practical action to undertake. I do not want to devalue Europe Mr Dell Alba LOC . I do not want to do shed the power to implement common policies on the contrary I want to consolidate accelerate and improve the decisions and implementation of common policies but at the same time I want to prevent our mechanisms becoming flooded with a large number of disjointed policies which in reality have little that is common about them. P P Let us remember how often we have been made into a laughing stock because we deal with things that are absolutely ridiculous which defy common sense and conflict with the interests of our population. Regarding this matter and this transformation the Commission can and must be a real leader relieved of useless burdens given more credibility because it takes tangible form in its core business and because it does not make requests but instead rejects unnecessary tasks and powers. The Commission must become a driving force. As Mr Cox PERSON said we should be an enabling Europe LOC not an including Europe LOC but very often we have been an enabling Europe LOC on the one hand and an including Europe LOC on the other. P My second ORDINAL guarantee is that these are not empty proposals. We have started work on them not just as regards the internal reform of the Commission together with Commissioner Kinnock PERSON but also in some initial reforms of the structure of individual policies. I shall give you an example if there is one CARDINAL policy that is important to the Commission it is competition policy. Well we have presented and in January DATE this House ORG supported these hypotheses with an overwhelming majority a programme for reform which will allow the Commission to concentrate on the fight against the most serious and important breaches of competition policy at European NORP level and we have begun a process of major cooperation with the national authorities on this. P We have done the same thing in the White Paper ORG regarding the food sector. I have heard this being criticised and I understand the criticism that it is has less powers than American Food and Drug Administration ORG . Well of course it does! I wanted to use the national authorities which are already active in this area. If I had used an organisational model such as the American NORP one you would now be rebelling and saying you have set up yet another centralised structure in Brussels GPE ! This is Europe LOC this delicate balance between existing national structures which must be enhanced and put in a network with the European authority ORG and not humiliated by its presence. Just as enlargement is a difficult challenge this is too because it has never before been attempted. P I welcome this broad unity over enlargement. There has hardly been any difference of opinion during this morning TIME s debate and I welcome that because enlargement is a decision that is going to entail sacrifice for us and great changes within ourselves. At the time of the actual decision here we shall all have to be united in order to demonstrate that enlargement is in the interests of peace prosperity and is taking place by way of a guarantee as I said before for our people in addition to a guarantee for the countries which are attempting to enlarge. P I have no intention to proceed to an enlargement process that is not serious strong and above all Mrs Muscardini was very attentive and made a justified remark about this enlargement must not produce two CARDINAL types of members the importance of enlargement stems precisely from the fact that once a country joins this Union it is the same as all the others. I said that we are a unity of minorities a union of minorities this is the extraordinary thing about the European Union ORG . But enlargement is also about being strict. I was reminded about the nuclear power stations and the Danube. I have just been to Lithuania GPE Slovakia GPE and Romania GPE three CARDINAL countries where we have had to request nuclear power stations to be closed. We did this mindful of the serious problems for the local economies but we explained that these are Europe LOC s rules and that this is a safety measure which everyone has to and will have to adopt. These countries understood that we have helped their transformation. They have undertaken to close the nuclear power plants which is an enormous sacrifice for them. But this is Europe LOC . Why the sacrifice? So that the goal which is in the common interest can be achieved. P It is also important to reach an agreement over Africa LOC . I have heard a lot of impassioned interventions about Africa LOC which I also mentioned in my speech because Africa LOC is one of the crosses we have to bear Africa LOC is neglected by everyone. I would remind you of the long journey the American NORP President made in recent years DATE which brought hope for a time but then nothing came of it. Africa LOC is principally one CARDINAL of our problems. Naturally it is included in the hierarchy of the analyses of foreign policy we mentioned earlier enlargement the Mediterranean Ukraine LOC Russia GPE and the question of Africa LOC which is under discussion. Preparations for the Summit are progressing but there are enormous difficulties there are terrible divisions in Africa LOC and I am trying to reduce them too I am trying to heal the rifts because if they remain it would become impossible to launch a major policy to help such a desperate Africa LOC . The Task Force ORG in the development DG is cooperating closely with the external relations DG in order to include new sectors in their work on Africa LOC too. We are starting to cooperate in the communication education and science sectors. If we do not act in these sectors of civilisation it will be impossible for Africa LOC to act. Nevertheless I am aware that we are still at the beginning and I would therefore ask for a great deal of openness and help from everyone. P I have also been rebuked for not having mentioned certain important sectors such as fisheries. It is true I did not mention fisheries and I did not even mention agriculture schools or the whole of the major social policy on the elderly. I did not mention it because I believe that the five year DATE programme must set out the major policy lines regarding general development but I am convinced of its enormous importance for cohesion and European NORP solidarity. I assure you that there will be a commitment in this area because it is clear that it is a piece of the important mosaic that we have outlined in today DATE s debate. P It is precisely with these essential functions with which we must ensure respect for our irreplaceable political and moral role at Europe LOC s helm that the Commission must strive to show the advantages and costs of our policies and to be very clear for a population that asks us for clarity that asks us to be absolutely transparent. In this regard I am reassured and encouraged by this debate. It reassures me because I have perceived a broad consensus on the basic lines of our programme and because I have the impression that its true substance has been understood. It has been a calm debate as I said at the start but not modest on the contrary it has been a debate with only a high political profile. So while the term manifesto might sound negative it does nevertheless have an important value of its own and a sound political content. We have talked to each other with a language that Mr Bar n Crespo PRODUCT described as plain and accessible. It emerged clearly but forcefully that the challenges before us are the great political challenges that we must tackle together. P This makes close collaboration between Parliament ORG and the Commission even more important. I am encouraged by this. There are those who have not been persuaded by the debate such as Mr Wurtz who said in his statement that he welcomed the constructive spirit and added we have five years DATE to succeed . We are ready to collaborate. This is what I want Mr Cox and not because I have ever noticed I am living in a honeymoon period. You said that the honeymoon is over. I remember the honeymoon as being somewhat different from the months DATE we spent together but I am pleased you used this term. In any case this debate has further convinced me that the major challenges that lie ahead are political challenges. They require great energy energy that will need to be intensified as the synergy between the institutions grows. P I would like to conclude by picking up on something Mr Bar n Crespo PRODUCT mentioned. He mentioned something that is very important to me Ambrogio Lorenzetti PERSON s fresco on Good Government in Siena GPE . If you recall it is a fresco where everything works. There are people working merchants and hierarchies which can easily be seen in that Sienese NORP society. It was a real five year DATE programme of the Community of Siena ORG it was their document whereby they tried to describe the society of the time. We can but admire this because after all it could serve as a point of reference. And Mr Bar n Crespo PRODUCT we cannot forget that the five year DATE programme was unable to exert any practical influence in the world it disappeared from political manifestos when Siena ORG s role in the world weakened. I think that we must avoid this danger. P SPEAKER ID 67 CARDINAL NAME van Hulten Mr President I should like to raise a point of order in relation to the activities organised today DATE by the Association of Parliamentary Assistants ORG in support of their call for a statute for assistants to be adopted as soon as possible. P I understand that on 26 January DATE the association wrote to the College of Quaestors ORG requesting permission to set up a table outside the Hemicycle PERSON today DATE to publicise their initiative. On the same day DATE I understand Mr Balfe gave permission for the assistants to go ahead. The Parliament ORG services asked to meet with the assistants yesterday DATE to make the necessary physical arrangements. However the appointment was cancelled at the last minute TIME . Parliament ORG has not yet indicated why permission was withdrawn. Mrs Banotti ORG apparently promised to write a letter explaining why permission was withdrawn but so far no letter has been received. P Can you explain why the approval given to the assistants was withdrawn at the last minute TIME ? Do you agree that the assistants have a legitimate case which must be heard? Will you do everything in your power to ensure that such last minute cancellations do not happen again? Will you do everything in your power to ensure that a statute for assistants is adopted as soon as possible? P Finally will you make sure that in the meantime Parliament ORG s rules are properly implemented and that assistants are paid as they should be on the basis of all the work they do for us? SPEAKER ID 70 CARDINAL NAME Banotti Mr President first of all let me say that I am in full support of a statute for assistants. Yesterday DATE when I arrived in Parliament ORG I was handed a document relating to a proposed demonstration by the assistants outside the doors of Parliament ORG . As all colleagues will know and many of you have approached me over the last six months DATE all exhibitions and such like are filtered first ORDINAL of all through the Comart ORG committee of Parliament ORG . To give a non contentious example no commercial exhibitions can be held here in Parliament ORG for obvious reasons. P Following a letter I received yesterday DATE I immediately informed the assistants that we would propose that they be allowed to hold a meeting or demonstration probably in the near future and possibly in the next month DATE . But all exhibitions must be carried out in a way that do not interfere with the orderly running of Parliament ORG . I signed a letter yesterday DATE afternoon TIME in the meeting of the Bureau of Parliament ORG in which the assistants were informed of this. But I am also told that they were informed verbally of this decision by the Committee of Chairmen of Groups ORG last Thursday DATE so they were fully aware of the decision. P There is no problem with them telling us the way they feel there is no problem with a possible meeting during Parliament ORG s next part session. But there was some misunderstanding for they did receive a letter from somebody else that they felt gave them permission. But all exhibitions are in fact looked at first ORDINAL by the so called Comart ORG committee. As you can see we have many exhibitions around Parliament ORG whether they be about different countries or whatever. This is not an attempt to either censor or go against the very real and justifiable principle that we should have a statute for assistants. FR PERSON The resolution which the European Parliament ORG has just adopted on immigration policy despite the Union for a Europe of Nations Group ORG voting against this retroactively justifies all the fears which we expressed when the Treaty of Amsterdam GPE was ratified. This House ORG has been utterly lax on the substance and yet at the same time is asking for ever greater decision making power to the detriment of the national parliaments. The combination of these two CARDINAL positions makes for a mixture which could be disastrous for the future for Europe LOC . P I counted no less than seven calls in the resolution at different points for equal rights for European NORP citizens and legal immigrants. This has become a real obsession. As for the fight against illegal immigration this House ORG is hardly interested. There is absolutely nothing in the resolution on border controls. Even when the question of Eurodac or readmission clauses is briefly mentioned it is only to deplore the over strictness of the Council on these subjects ORG . Yet the standard call for a fund for refugees financed from the Community ORG budget is there. P Finally the European Parliament ORG calls for a review of immigration policy in view of the population situation. It is clear what this means. At the same time the resolution calls for new codecision powers for the European Parliament ORG on immigration. You can imagine what would come of this. As was to be expected the Commission has just lent its support in the opinion tabled for the Intergovernmental Conference ORG . P Our group believes that it would be dangerous to go down this road. Instead on these matters we should stick with the people and national sovereignty. This is why the procedures of the first ORDINAL pillar on the single market must not be transposed exactly as they are for the areas of security justice or foreign policy. For these areas the Intergovernmental Conference must devise new cooperation procedures based on the political role of the Council ORG and interparliamentary control exercised by the national parliaments. P SPEAKER ID 75 LANGUAGE ES NAME Palacio Vallelersundi Mr PERSON President I am speaking on behalf of the Spanish NORP delegation of the European People s Party ORG the delegation of the Spanish People s Party ORG with regard to Mrs Terr PERSON n i Cus s resolution on the area of freedom security and justice. P There have been some votes where we have not followed the guidelines of the Group of the European People s Party and we have voted in favour of the Terr PERSON n i Cus resolution which we consider on the whole to be excellent. However we have voted against paragraphs 2 CARDINAL and 6 because they seem to us to be legally incorrect. P On the other hand we have voted in favour of Recital NORP J which in fact is in line with what I as draftsperson of the opinion of the Committee on Citizens Freedoms ORG proposed to that Committee ORG with a view to the Intergovernmental Conference. We have also voted in favour of paragraph 13 CARDINAL . An appropriate statute and the right of movement and settlement for residents of non EU ORG countries is something which the Spanish People s Party ORG has been advocating for some time. P For similar reasons we have voted in favour of paragraph 14 which with the oral amendment dealt with certain very justifiable concerns about the question of subsidiarity since political rights not just voting in local elections but political rights in general terms form part of the sovereignty of Member States. Given the oral amendment we felt we could vote in favour and that is what we have done. SPEAKER ID 76 LANGUAGE DA NAME Blak and Lund . DA The Danish Social Democratic Members ORG of the European Parliament ORG have chosen to vote in favour of the proposed resolution but are at the same time aware of the fact that certain areas clash with the reservation Denmark GPE has in the legal sphere a reservation which the Danish NORP delegation in the Group of the Party of European Socialists ORG naturally wishes to respect. SPEAKER ID 77 LANGUAGE FR NAME Krivine This report which I voted against is less concerned with human rights than with communitisation or the consolidation of Fortress Europe LOC . The supposed progress achieved in 1999 DATE and mentioned by the report only occurred in the Dublin Conventions and Schengen Agreements ORG and a further action plan from Tampere which all restrict the rights of immigrants. In terms of human rights this is a backward step. Europe LOC is continuing to expel nationals arriving from countries regarded as dangerous by the Office of the United Nations ORG High Commissioner for Refugees. Yet some applicant countries in central and eastern Europe LOC are taking in gypsy refugees expelled en masse from Belgium GPE . Kosovo Albanians NORP and Serb NORP deserters are being refused refugee status whereas Pinochet GPE is calmly escaping prosecution. The Europe of Schengen ORG clearly finds it much easier to hound the persecuted from the south than dictators even though the UN ORG estimates that we will need 159 million CARDINAL immigrants to maintain a stable population between now and the year 2025 DATE . P Europe LOC should regularise the situation of all its illegal immigrants and grant them right of asylum and the right to vote in all elections. Only then can we talk in this House ORG about an area of freedom and justice. P McCarthy PERSON report A5 0026 2000 DATE SPEAKER ID 78 LANGUAGE ES NAME Ortuondo Larrea PERSON Mr President I would firstly like to point out that I was Mayor of Bilbao GPE during the nineties DATE which gave me the opportunity to present one CARDINAL of the first ORDINAL urban pilot projects to be subsidised by the Commission. Our experience with that pilot project in Bilbao GPE led us to four CARDINAL conclusions firstly that Europe LOC must maintain an urban policy and therefore far from reducing the EUR 900 million LAW for the last five year DATE period to EUR 700 million LAW for this five year DATE period the funding of this project should be increased. This should be done for example and the Group of the Greens European Free Alliance ORG has proposed this by reinvesting in URBAN projects that portion of the Structural Funds which each Member State has not spent within the time scales laid down for that purpose. P Secondly ORDINAL when deciding which areas must be subsidised we must concentrate efforts on integrated projects. Disparate actions are not effective. We have to select locations by prioritising those which are most impoverished and needy in accordance with the objectives set that is to say the social economic environmental and democratic management dimensions as well as the relationship between them. P Thirdly ORDINAL we have to bear in mind the synergies generated by other Community ORG programmes as well as the opportunities for sustainable development in the location or region in question. P Finally we have to put our trust in and support the institutions which are closest to the citizens that is the local councils and bodies. They have more first ORDINAL hand knowledge of social needs. They have more involvement in the problems and furthermore they know how to conceive projects and implement them effectively without weighing them down with bureaucracy and thereby achieve better results. P Lastly in today DATE s vote on our four CARDINAL amendments two CARDINAL have been approved and the other two rejected. This has obliged us to abstain from the final vote because we do not understand how we can ignore the environmental question when deciding which projects must be financed and we do not understand how we can reject the idea that each Member State can dedicate to URBAN projects that portion of the Structural Funds which it has not spent in accordance with Community programmes. SPEAKER ID 79 CARDINAL NAME Isler B guin Mr President the Committee on Regional Policy Transport and Tourism ORG had an in depth discussion on the URBAN ORG initiative which produced many ideas. As the smallest Community ORG initiative in existence we therefore proposed an increase in its funding through an amendment which was rejected. We regret this as there was actually money left over from the Structural Funds ORG in some countries which could really have helped with pilot projects. We should remember that it is these URBAN projects which specifically allow a truly urban policy to be established. The Commission should also pay attention to coherence between the various policies which are in place. It should make URBAN projects coherent with future projects in budget lines entitled sustainable urban policy . P Finally there is currently still no European NORP urban policy within the European Union ORG . Perhaps this point could be developed in the context of reorganisation and the Intergovernmental Conference so that the European Union ORG finally has a true urban policy. SPEAKER ID 80 LANGUAGE IT NAME Fatuzzo Mr President I would like to point out that I voted for this report on sustainable urban development known as URBAN ORG . As with all other Community ORG initiatives this is very positive. Europe LOC is making its presence felt at a time when we are doing something for all the citizens of Europe LOC and not simply for the development of an individual State ORG whichever one it may be. P URBAN is designed to find solutions to urban decay and this is something of great concern to the elderly and therefore of great concern to the Pensioners Party ORG . There can be no worse situation than that of an elderly person living in a city. I hope that this Community ORG initiative will help serve as an example on how to resolve the problems faced by the elderly in cities. SPEAKER ID 82 LANGUAGE DA NAME Bonde Krarup Okking and Sandb k . DA We have voted in favour of the report on the communication from the Commission concerning the guidelines for a Community ORG initiative relating to the economic and social regeneration of cities and neighbourhoods in crisis and designed to promote sustainable development URBAN . Basically we are opposed to programmes and structural funds of this type but since the vote only concerns how and not to what extent these resources are to be used we have confined ourselves to assessing the contents and think in general that the proposal for regenerating neighbourhoods in crisis contains some sensible observations as well as some good suggestions and criteria for the relevant projects. SPEAKER ID 83 LANGUAGE FR NAME Bordes Cauquil WORK_OF_ART and Laguiller PERSON This report contains general points on what is referred to as the urban regeneration strategy for town centres and neighbourhoods affected by the crisis in the capitalist economy and its consequences i.e. increasing unemployment exclusion and delinquency. P It underlines the fact that in order to ensure sustainable urban development an urban policy must be implemented which does not leave out the main victims of the economic crisis namely the unemployed immigrants refugees women and the socially excluded. P However nothing is said about the causes of this crisis and those responsible for it. At best this report simply corrects certain aspects and effects of the crisis. Yet only scandalously limited resources are available for this work. As the report itself indicates the funds allocated to the URBAN II EVENT programme for the 2000 2006 period are approximately 30 CARDINAL less than those in the previous period which were already low at EUR 900 million ORG . Added to this is the fact that only about fifty CARDINAL projects are considered for the whole of Europe LOC which is pathetic when practically all European NORP city districts both suburban and inner city are affected. This is why we will vote individually in favour of the specific measures planned to help certain social categories which are most disadvantaged but will abstain on the report itself in order to denounce the fact that in the main it consists of pious hopes financed on the cheap. SPEAKER ID 84 CARDINAL NAME Caudron FR PERSON Mrs McCarthy PERSON ladies and gentlemen I am very pleased that the URBAN Community Initiative is being continued as this aims to support the social and economic conversion of cities and neighbourhoods in crisis all with a view to achieving sustainable urban development. P With some 80 CARDINAL of the population of Europe LOC living in an urban area cities are at the forefront of economic social and cultural change in Europe LOC . At the same time the social and economic problems facing European NORP society are more pronounced in urban areas. Many European NORP cities are divided into neighbourhoods characterised by high added value activities and high income residents and other districts characterised by low incomes high unemployment substandard and overcrowded housing and high levels of welfare dependency. P The concentration of economic and social problems in certain urban areas calls for targeted intervention taking full account of the complexity of the problems involved. This is why the European Parliament ORG successfully called for the URBAN Community Initiative or CIP to be extended during the reform of the Structural Funds. P The success of URBAN during the 1994 1999 DATE programming period is indisputable. The results are clear in terms of the improvement of the quality of life in the target areas. This CIP ORG has encouraged the development of best practice models in the economic social and environmental sectors. It has also had the distinction of strengthening the role of local authorities the non governmental sector and local communities and of supporting new partnership approaches to urban regeneration. P The new initiative will continue to pursue these goals by reinforcing them while particularly promoting equal opportunities between men and women and integrating socially marginalised and disadvantaged groups. We can therefore welcome its adoption. P We must however admit that in financial terms we cannot proclaim a victory! The total appropriation allocated is not up to the challenge. The amount for the 1994 1999 DATE period was EUR 900 million CARDINAL and will be EUR 700 million CARDINAL for the 2000 2006 period. This represents a drop of 30 CARDINAL ! This reduction in funding has led to a reduction in the number of programmes in the new URBAN initiative. The chosen threshold of 50 CARDINAL projects seems too low. It needs to be increased to reflect regional and local factors whilst maintaining financial awards to the Member States. P In view of this concentration on a limited number of projects the publication and dissemination of the results of the new URBAN Community Initiative ORG will perhaps be particularly important to achieve a multiplier effect. SPEAKER ID 85 LANGUAGE PT NAME Figueiredo The Commission ORG s proposal reduces the number of urban areas that could benefit from the new URBAN ORG programme in the period 2000 2006 DATE from more than 100 CARDINAL to only 50. It also reduces appropriations by 30 CARDINAL . P Portugal GPE will suffer unfairly as a result of this proposal in spite of the fact that it already has greater needs in this area than any other country in the European Union ORG . There has been a reduction in that only two CARDINAL projects will be financed whereas in Germany GPE ten CARDINAL have been planned nine CARDINAL in the United Kingdom GPE and eight CARDINAL in Italy GPE . P P So far Portugal GPE has had six CARDINAL projects financed on behalf of the municipal authorities of Oporto Gondomar Lisbon ORG Odivelas Oeiras PERSON and Amadora GPE . P It is therefore crucial that the Commission ORG review its position particularly in terms of the way in which it allocates projects to Portugal GPE in order to maintain the important task of providing social and economic renewal for urban and suburban areas which will guarantee sustainable urban development. SPEAKER ID 86 LANGUAGE FR NAME Marchiani The McCarthy PERSON report on the URBAN Community Initiative gives us an opportunity to reflect on the appropriateness of Community ORG intervention in urban matters. The situation of certain urban areas is alarming with the social distress taking the form of unemployment misery and crime. Drug dealing in particular fuels insecurity and delinquency. P Faced with these social challenges the effectiveness of the Structural Funds is still in doubt. Subsidiarity should make us realise that the state exercising its governing functions and local authorities are the bodies most able to intervene appropriately. The state can ensure public safety and the local authorities can help disadvantaged people. Although we welcome the determination to create a system of exchanges between successful enterprises the problems specific to each urban area cannot be dealt with in the same way. P The URBAN Community Initiative is helping to achieve the European Union s desire to communitise urban policy. It would be more appropriate for the EU ORG to concentrate its financial efforts on pre existing European NORP policies. Clearly some people are profiting from the opportunity to indulge in another budget bidding race which is particularly mistimed when the convergence criteria for EMU ORG are imposing a very strict slimming regime on the national budgets. Mrs McCarthy PERSON is therefore suggesting an increase in the funds allocated to URBAN and the promotion of this Community ORG initiative through a costly communication campaign extolling the benefits of a federal Europe LOC . We should remember that the effectiveness of expenditure is not measured by the volume of funding allocated to the project. In fact the beneficiaries of too many and too high subsidies will eventually just take these for granted. The aim must not be to help the people but to make them take responsibility. P Finally the report specifically highlights actions in favour of ethnic or sociological minorities. We can only condemn a policy on minorities which is inevitably dangerous for social cohesion. On one CARDINAL hand this policy encourages the integration of immigrants where it should favour their assimilation into the culture of the host country. This would prevent the development of ethnic ghettos which are nothing more than urban powder kegs. On the other hand it manipulates the principle of positive discrimination. This is a politically correct fancy which can be just as harmful as shown by the US GPE precedent. P For all these reasons the French NORP delegation of the UEN Group ORG could not approve the McCarthy PERSON report. P Decourri PERSON re report A5 0028 2000 DATE SPEAKER ID 87 CARDINAL NAME Isler B guin Mr President the INTERREG ORG programme is particularly close to our hearts. Like many of my colleagues I am pleased that the European Parliament ORG was able to safeguard this initiative. As I live in the Sarre PERSON Lor Lux Sud region of Belgium GPE I am well aware that the regions are where Europe LOC is being created. They are where we live the European NORP experience on a daily DATE basis and where the people make European NORP construction come alive. These projects must therefore be properly taken into account and must integrate sustainable development. Why am I stressing this point? The answer is quite simply because the projects currently being submitted are still too often damaging to the environment due to the way they are submitted. For example to accept new roads is to accept new pollution within the European Union ORG . This goes totally against the policies which we are proposing to fight greenhouse gas emissions for example. P I would also ask the Commission to ensure that the environmental pillar of the EU ORG s policy is integrated into the projects submitted and that the goal of reducing CO2 for example forms an experimental added value in the projects proposed. I am particularly thinking in this respect of certain infrastructures which are under construction. We know that some Member States are still wavering for example between rail and road for routes through vulnerable areas such as the Pyrenees as in the Aspe valley. However I am also thinking of my own region where my government is still debating whether to route the railway or to build a second ORDINAL motorway the A32 PRODUCT . In this respect too I would ask the Commission to be particularly attentive about ensuring that there is real cohesion between the various policies specifically in the INTERREG ORG programmes which are being submitted. SPEAKER ID 88 LANGUAGE IT NAME Fatuzzo Mr President I voted for the Decourri PERSON re report on the Community ORG initiative INTERREG mainly because of the reply Commissioner Barnier PERSON gave to some Members who took the floor and asked for this programme to make greater reference to border regions with maritime frontiers. I voted for it not just because I was born in a coastal town Genoa PERSON but above all because the frontiers of regions bordered by the sea are frontiers too. P These frontiers stretch as far as African NORP states and the Middle East LOC we must take greater account of the fact that it is also important to develop coastal regions in every part of Europe LOC . SPEAKER ID 89 LANGUAGE FR NAME Caudron As an MEP ORG from a border region I welcome this third ORDINAL INTERREG initiative with great interest. P We can never talk enough about the difficulties experienced in the past by maritime and landlocked border regions which have been cut off economically socially and culturally. Due to the existence of these borders they have become peripheral areas within the countries to which they belong. This has too often led the national authorities to neglect these regions in national policy. P This is why the INTERREG Community Initiative ORG was launched in 1990 DATE . This programme was designed to encourage cross border transnational and interregional cooperation and to promote balanced development of the Community ORG territory in order to enhance economic and social cohesion in the Union. INTERREG serves principally to fund Community ORG schemes to develop SMEs education and training cultural exchanges action to combat health problems the protection and improvement of the environment energy transport and telecommunications networks. P I must stress that interregional cooperation significantly encourages the involvement of local and regional authorities in the process of European NORP integration. More active participation by these authorities in Community ORG initiatives should be promoted bearing in mind that in many cases they have a very limited capacity for cooperation because of the different legal frameworks and different levels of development on either side of the border. P In cross border cooperation greater emphasis must be placed on improving the conditions for the economic activity of the small and medium sized undertakings which are the job creators. In the same respect given that structural unemployment is responsible for 50 CARDINAL of all unemployment the INTERREG ORG funds made available must be sufficient to supplement national measures promoting employment. Obstacles too often caused by double taxation and social protection are preventing braking or hindering cross border mobility. I hope that the projects included within the programmes can help to provide solutions to these problems and to implement in practical terms the principle of free movement of workers which is in a bad way in my region! INTERREG resources must also contribute to the development of a European NORP research area. P Finally and in particular expectations in the regions about this initiative are high given that small towns not eligible for Objective 2 funding are hoping to obtain compensation through INTERREG! The challenges are therefore immense. The integration of the border regions will be an essential element in the development of a future European NORP regional development policy! I hope everyone like Mr Decourri re whom I congratulate will realise this! SPEAKER ID 90 CARDINAL NAME Lang FR PERSON The INTERREG Community Initiative is just one CARDINAL element of an ill fated European NORP regional policy. P This apparently generous policy officially intended to help problem regions is a fool s bargain for French NORP taxpayers. France GPE contributes 17 CARDINAL of the European NORP budget yet will receive only 8 CARDINAL of the regional Structural Funds ORG . Between 1994 and 1999 DATE our regions annually DATE received an average of FF 15.4 billion ORG but will receive only FF ORG 14.7 billion MONEY between 2000 and 2006 DATE . P My region of Nord Pas de Calais FAC will be particularly affected with French Hainaut PERSON losing the aid paid to Objective 1 CARDINAL regions. This loss is unjustified in a region whose main activities have been ruined by free trade Europe LOC . P The European NORP regional policy also reinforces the centralism of Brussels GPE with which the regional authorities are invited to negotiate directly on the use of the Structural Funds. This is a Europe LOC of regions in which the regions which are weaker than the nation states will easily submit to Brussels GPE . P The INTERREG ORG initiative launched in 1990 DATE to prepare the border regions for a Europe LOC without borders and therefore without nations sits comfortably within this philosophy. P However Mr Decourri re does show some common sense by denouncing the failings of the Brussels GPE technocrats. These failings will result in particular in the late implementation of INTERREG III FAC and therefore in financial losses for the regions in receipt of aid. We also agree with the rapporteur about asking for more attention to be paid to small and medium sized undertakings and of course about refusing to use outside service providers. These are the procedures which caused the corruption scandal in the previous Commission. P However these isolated elements which make sense and for which we voted in no way remedy the Eurofederalist NORP philosophy which characterises the Community ORG initiatives particularly INTERREG. This is why the National Front ORG voted against the report. SPEAKER ID 91 CARDINAL LANGUAGE FR NAME Poignant The European Parliament ORG has delivered an opinion on the Commission guidelines for the INTERREG Community Initiative ORG concerning cross border transnational and interregional cooperation. P I want to defend an amendment tabled by my group on the maritime aspect of this Community ORG initiative. This does not involve the concerns about the future of the Atlantic Arc LOC but rather the need to integrate the principle of maritime borders into strand A on cross border cooperation. P In the Commission guidelines few maritime areas are eligible for INTERREG IIIA ORG . The amendments to the Decourri re report aim to make INTERREG ORG more maritime oriented. This is an important development which must be supported as it is the future of the EU ORG which is at stake. I am aware of the Commission ORG s reluctance on this subject as it announced during the symposium on the presentation of INTERREG III ORG last November DATE . However I must point out that preventing the recognition of maritime borders amounts to denying the existence of an area which has great potential for projects and innovation. P One CARDINAL example of this is the Celtic LOC area which encompasses the territories of Brittany PERSON in France Cornwall GPE and Devon PERSON in the United Kingdom GPE and Cork and Waterford GPE in Ireland GPE . This is an area whose locally based economy is characterised by dependence on the fishing industry and the importance of the agri foodstuffs sector. It also has excellent cultural and relational links through twinnings for example. INTERREG III strand A would allow the regions in this area to advance a number of structural projects needed to develop small and medium sized undertakings and to promote research and technical development through knowledge transfer. P The European Commission ORG should therefore be able to participate in the construction of port and airport infrastructure to provide links between regions. This policy would have important economic consequences for the fishing industry in Brittany PERSON in that catches could be unloaded at Irish NORP advance bases in order to then be transported to the Breton FAC agri foodstuffs industry. P The integration of the maritime border into strand A would finally allow the western periphery to be recognised as a unique and important economic area which is confronted by the continentalisation of the European Union ORG . This would show respect for these peripheral areas which are rather concerned about enlargement to the east. P The maritime world has great potential. We therefore must not leave it out of innovative and pilot Community programmes which will allow the new geographical and economic map of Europe LOC to be defined. SPEAKER ID 92 LANGUAGE DA NAME Rovsing . DA The European NORP project began as a partnership between States GPE . This partnership has ensured peace and stability in our part of Europe LOC for over 50 years DATE . As a result of the economic and political success in our part of the world of which the EU ORG is just one CARDINAL proof and in view of the ever greater proliferation of our Western values competition on the world market has grown considerably within the last few decades DATE . P The EU ORG should be prepared to meet that competition. We can only do that by intensifying co operation within the Community ORG . It should not be about greater integration of the EU ORG countries in the form of a federation but about using our economic potential across national borders. It is about co operating on joint projects and about unifying forces on all sides. A programme such as INTERREG ORG is there precisely to support regional development projects across national borders projects which make it possible to build centres of economic growth at European NORP level which will be able to take up the challenge from our competitors on a global scale. I therefore welcome the continuation of the programme. SPEAKER ID 93 LANGUAGE FR NAME Thomas Mauro PERSON . FR PERSON Mr Decourri re s PERSON report is not without merit at the end of a clear and comprehensive presentation of the INTERREG ORG initiative and its role in opening up border regions it comes out in favour of SMEs in paragraph 16 DATE . P I and my colleague Dominique Souchet PERSON who is well versed in this matter have tabled five CARDINAL amendments highlighting the role of SMEs and craft trades within the framework of INTERREG the importance of cooperation between undertakings and the need to involve economic and social partners in the design and implementation of the programmes and I welcome the fact that these amendments were adopted unanimously. P Nonetheless the French NORP delegation in our group was unable to accept the fact that the Commission and the federalist faction have diverted the INTERREG ORG initiative from its original purpose in order to detract still further from the political role of the nations. We have no intention of giving Brussels GPE the job of regulating regional planning in the Member States as suggested in recital of the report. We only ask one CARDINAL thing of the Commission that it confine itself to ensuring that the implementation of joint policies does not upset the balance of regional planning in our territories. The destructive effects of the CAP ORG and EMU ORG on the balance between regions especially on the vitality of the more rural the more remote and the least populated regions is proof positive of the fact that such ambitions are not a sinecure far from it. P We are therefore unable to approve the development of strand IIIC of the Community ORG initiative encouraging interregional cooperation under the responsibility of the Commission and sidelining the Member States. This infatuation with strand IIIC is all the stranger in that the rapporteur himself acknowledges in his explanatory statement that the draft guidelines do not provide any indication of possible fields of co operation p.17 and that the responsibilities are diffuse and vague p.18 . Calling under these circumstances as he does in paragraph 20 CARDINAL for the budget for this strand to be increased is another example of the irresponsible and ideological outbidding tactics which are customary in this House ORG . P Lastly there is the desire expressed both in the Commission document and Mr Decourri re s PERSON report of using INTERREG ORG for peace and reconstruction in the Balkans LOC I do not think that the Structural Funds should be used to repair the damage which the Americans NORP inflicted on Serbia GPE during bombardments which were as criminal as they were ineffectual. It is up to Washington GPE not us to assume responsibility for a conflict which was triggered merely to serve its interests. P The French NORP delegation in our group is therefore unable to support the Decourri GPE re report and will choose to abstain during the final vote. P Procacci PERSON report A5 CARDINAL 0025 2000 SPEAKER ID 94 LANGUAGE IT NAME Fatuzzo Mr President I voted for the Procacci PERSON report on rural development not only because I endorse the major policy lines of the LEADER ORG programme but also because it complements the URBAN ORG programme which I spoke about earlier. However first I should like to take this opportunity to express my full support for the focal points of the Commission ORG s new programme. P That applies in particular to the integrated multisectoral approach which is gaining ground in the agricultural sector and which is highlighted time and again by national agricultural ministers in the Member States. And greater emphasis on environmental protection in connection with rural areas in general is extremely important for the future of all of us. Referring to farmers as the guardians of the countryside best expresses the preferred direction of future agricultural policy and of course its transposition. P I also take it as a good sign that thanks to one of the most fundamental changes to the LEADER ORG programme all rural areas and hence 80 CARDINAL of the total area of the European Union ORG and 25 CARDINAL of the people in the 15 CARDINAL Member States will be able to benefit from the programme. In addition and this is what concerns me most still no provision has been made for initiatives geared to mountain areas.
