P Thank you for your attention. SPEAKER ID 96 LANGUAGE PT NAME Figueiredo PT PERSON Although this Community initiative LEADER ORG follows on from previous initiatives it has some unique features. One CARDINAL of these of course is the reduction by around one half CARDINAL in appropriations made available even though they will cover a longer period. Nevertheless new objectives have been included specifically the financing of the Nature Network 2000 for which all rural regions will be eligible. P In spite of the fact that this Community ORG initiative is aimed at rural development it does not address the issues of agriculture and agricultural production in a consistent way and this is unacceptable. Without agriculture the rural world will disappear. This means that any strategy for rural development must be based on agriculture s internal potential while at the same time developing as many other activities as possible in order to prevent the desertification of the rural world. P This is why we considered it essential to improve the report by means of our proposals deliberately to include agricultural activity and farmers in the strategy for rural development and to request more appropriations in order not to threaten the survival of the programme in those rural regions which were covered before. We also want to ensure that the new programme continues to prioritise the less favoured regions. SPEAKER ID 97 LANGUAGE EL NAME Korakas Our position on LEADER ORG is a product of our more general assessment of the EU ORG s overall agricultural policy. Both LEADER 1 and LEADER 2 which were implemented in the 1990s DATE were ingredients of the new CAP ORG that emerged after its review in 1992 DATE and along with other respective measures they constituted the so termed second ORDINAL pillar of the EU ORG s rural development policy. Their real aim was to moderate and disguise the new CAP ORG s disastrous consequences and the disorientation of small and medium scale farmers and not to develop the rural areas or retain the agricultural population therein as was hypocritically declared in their objectives. This is proved by the fact that in the areas where those initiatives were implemented farming incomes and employment decreased rapidly which resulted in their depopulation. A characteristic example is Greece GPE which as an Objective 1 country was included as a whole in the LEADER Community initiatives and where the average annual reduction in employment in the farming sector reached approximately 2.3 CARDINAL while between 1994 and 1999 DATE farming incomes decreased by 15.2 CARDINAL . P We think LEADER will be even more ineffectual than LEADER 1 and LEADER 2 for the following reasons. P The real aims of LEADER ORG are the same as those of LEADERs 1 and 2 PERSON in other words to moderate and disguise the negative consequences of the CAP ORG to be implemented in the context of Agenda 2000 and the WTO ORG . The present CAP ORG however is worse than its predecessor and it also starts from a worse basis granted that the 1992 DATE CAP ORG review and the GATT ORG agreement in 1995 DATE have created serious problems and impasses for the agricultural economy. The selection criteria and the activities that are subsidised under LEADER ORG do in the best case moderate some partial problems of the countryside which are of secondary importance but in the worst case they degenerate into expenditure for the sake of public relations and pandering to conscience. In no case however are they programmes for the integrated development of the selected areas and they do not create permanent jobs in the countryside because most of the activities there are not productive in nature. P The actual appropriations available for LEADER ORG compared with LEADER 2 CARDINAL are smaller despite their increase by 15 CARDINAL from EUR 1 775 million CARDINAL for LEADER 2 CARDINAL to EUR 2 020 million CARDINAL for LEADER ORG . This is because the 15 CARDINAL increase is nominal and not real granted that average yearly inflation in the Community ORG during those years was approximately 2 . LEADER ORG will last a year longer than LEADER 2 CARDINAL . LEADER can cover all the regions of the EU ORG while LEADER 2 CARDINAL covered only the Objective 1 CARDINAL regions and some Objective 5b and 6 CARDINAL regions. We must point out however that even if the actual appropriations available for LEADER ORG were increased the Community ORG initiative would still be ineffectual because such programmes cannot compensate for or blunt the anti farming nature of the CAP ORG that will be implemented in the context of Agenda 2000 and the WTO ORG . The real outcome of such programmes is to act as a cover up to lead people off the scent and to salve consciences. P We disagree with many of the report s views. Once more we point to the negative changes of the CAP 1992 Agenda 2000 . We do not think LEADER ORG will contribute substantively towards solving the countryside s problems which are characterised by the decline of farming which was and should remain the countryside s basic social and economic branch. For our part we will tell the farmers about the expediency of these programmes. We will make every effort to improve them as much as possible and prevent them from being wasted and most important of all we will try to foster the struggle of farmers against the disastrous CAP ORG which is disinheriting them and leading them towards economic decline and the desertion of the countryside. Unless this CAP ORG is overthrown no programme can ensure the survival of small and medium scale farmers and the social and economic regeneration of the countryside. SPEAKER ID 98 LANGUAGE FR NAME Souchet All the Members in the Union for a Europe of Nations Group voted in favour of almost the whole of the Procacci PERSON report on the LEADER Community Initiative. However we amended the draft report adopted by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development ORG in order to clarify certain points which will make this Community initiative more effective. P In particular we felt it was necessary to simplify the administrative and financial procedures which proved to be too cumbersome and slow in the LEADER II ORG initiative. It was also essential to ensure that better account is taken of the development priorities of local operators and that the benefit of LEADER funds is not limited solely to agricultural regions with a low population density. P Amendment No 10 which I tabled on behalf of my group refers to the concept of economic and social cohesion rather than regional development as the European Union ORG does not have any recognised competence in this area. P Amendment No 11 replaces government or municipal officials with government officials . Although local action groups should consist of a balanced and representative selection of partners drawn from the different socio economic sectors of the territory concerned government officials must be involved at decision making level whether they come from the municipalities departments regions or national governments. The rapporteur s phrasing was therefore too limiting. P Amendment No 12 responds to the expectations of the Committee on Regional Policy Transport and Tourism of this House ORG . It specifies the necessary coordination between LEADER ORG and Community ORG cooperation and partnership programmes such as INTERREG PHARE Sapard ORG or MEDA LOC . In the territory of Member States of the European Union ORG applicant countries or Member States of EFTA there may be interrelations between the various Community ORG initiatives. The real priority for the European NORP continent is to establish an operational level within a European NORP framework and not a global framework as proposed by the rapporteur. The creation of organisations similar to the LAGs may be usefully encouraged by the European Union ORG provided that the corresponding costs are borne by the various partners. P In essence we are of course in favour of this LEADER Community Initiative. The conference on rural development held in Cork GPE from 7 to 9 DATE November 1996 DATE set rural development as one CARDINAL of the European Union s priorities since it is essential to preserve the integrity of our agriculture and the whole rural fabric including infrastructure public and private services and so on. In this context in committee we regretted the paltry funding allotted to rural development and supported the amendments calling for an increased budget for this Community ORG initiative so that it matches the previous LEADER I and LEADER II initiatives. The budget allocated to LEADER for a period of seven years DATE is half CARDINAL that allocated to LEADER II ORG for a period of six years DATE . This is unacceptable given the importance of rural development and the consequences for farmers of the fall in prices and aid specified in the reform of the CAP ORG following the Berlin GPE agreements. P Finally among the priority parameters to be introduced at European NORP level to enable local involvement particular attention must be paid to the quality and originality of projects which have already been implemented by LAGs within the LEADER II ORG initiative but which could not be concluded due to the timetable and weight of the management mechanisms specified. P The sitting was suspended at 1.40 p.m. TIME and resumed at 3 p.m. CHAPTER ID 6 Additives in feedingstuffs SPEAKER ID 99 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is the report A5 0015 2000 PRODUCT by Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development ORG on the proposal for a Council ORG directive amending Directive 70 524 DATE EEC concerning additives in feedingstuffs COM 1999 DATE 388 C5 0134 1999 1999 DATE 0168 CNS EVENT . SPEAKER ID 100 LANGUAGE DE NAME Graefe zu Baringdorf Mr ORG President Commissioner Byrne PERSON under Directive 70 524 CARDINAL high technology additives are treated differently depending on the date of authorisation. The Commission ORG has proposed harmonising the authorisation procedure so that substances licensed before 1988 DATE are put on an equal footing with substances authorised now. As far as we in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development ORG are concerned so far so good. P However the directive also encompasses the authorisation of antibiotics drugs growth promoters and genetically modified organisms. That makes it a question of health not just approximating laws which is why we in the Committee on Agriculture ORG take the view that the legal base Article 37 LAW is not admissible here and that the Commission should submit its proposal to us on the basis of Article 152 LAW that is to say with codecision by Parliament ORG . We asked the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs ORG and the Internal Market ORG which pointed out that as far as approximating laws is concerned Article 37 LAW is adequate in this case. However we in the Committee on Agriculture ORG have not confined ourselves to approximating laws because this proposal also encompasses genetically modified organisms we have tabled a further proposed amendment which affects the content and hence public health. P We negotiated with the Commission for two years DATE on the seed directive and came to a compromise regulating the release of genetically modified organisms in the directive taking the text on which Directive 70 524 CARDINAL is based as a starting point. Mr Byrne PERSON we fail to understand why the Commission is not approximating the text on genetically modified organisms as part of its harmonisation work. We have now tabled a proposed amendment on precisely this compromise with the Commission on the text. Moreover this text has also been adopted in the forest directive on the use of forest reproductive material and we feel that this text urgently needs to be adopted in this directive as well. The Commission pointed out in committee that it plans to present a novel feed directive in the future. However that should not prevent us from harmonising the text in order to ensure that there is no legal uncertainty between the various directives. We are therefore assuming that you will accept our proposed amendment with regard to genetically modified organisms. P Directive 70 524 CARDINAL still contains the old text because the seed directive was submitted to Parliament ORG in 1986 DATE and we then negotiated with the Commission ORG until 1988 DATE while the report on this directive was dealt with in 1994 DATE and Parliament ORG obviously did not accord genetically modified organisms the same importance then as it did later when I was rapporteur. We therefore assume Commissioner Byrne PERSON that you too will accept our proposed amendment of the legal base. If you do not we must reserve the right to refer this report back to committee and then negotiate this sensitive point with you exactly as we did with the seed directive. I should point out that the text which we have now worked out is a valid compromise both for your legal service and ours. In other words we do not need to re negotiate the text we merely need to adopt this text in the directive. I can hardly wait Commissioner Byrne PERSON to hear what you have to say to our proposals. P SPEAKER ID 101 LANGUAGE DE NAME Keppelhoff Wiechert PERSON Mr President Commissioner does regulating additives in feedingstuffs come under competition or consumer policy? As far the Commission and the Legal Affairs Committee ORG are concerned it comes under competition. Of course we have to take account of the competitiveness of the feedingstuffs industry by harmonising provisions for substances authorised before and after 1988 DATE . We want to prevent the prices of feedingstuffs from rising and Mr Doyle s proposed Amendments Nos 4 and 5 CARDINAL therefore deserve our support. P However as Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf ORG has said in his report this is first ORDINAL and foremost a consumer policy matter. Food safety must take absolute priority over feedingstuffs in all our discussions. When we talk of transparency in the food chain that applies from the hayfork to the table fork and consumer protection therefore logically starts with feedingstuffs. The antibiotics growth promoters and genetically modified organisms mixed in with feedingstuffs end up in the human food chain. The dioxin scandal brought home to us that we have to get out of this mess once and for all and regulating additives in feedingstuffs is a step in the right direction. P According to Article 152 of LAW the EC Treaty ORG we are obliged to obviate sources of danger to human health whereby the accent is clearly on sources. Consequently we must cut off the supply of the original source of danger i.e. harmful additives in feedingstuffs. Otherwise in my view we are beavering away at the symptoms but not the causes. People are especially wary of GMOs. We must confront increasing public awareness of GMOs by regulating their use in feedingstuffs accordingly. P First ORDINAL if an additive consists of or contains genetically modified organisms then it should only be authorised if it poses no risk to human health or the environment. Secondly ORDINAL it makes sense to issue provisions for genetically modified feedingstuff additives similar to the regulations in seed marketing legislation as the rapporteur has said. And thirdly ORDINAL if we are to have a transparent consumer policy we need to label genetically modified feedingstuffs. A clear declaration on feedingstuffs will allow double freedom of choice both for the party using the feedingstuff and the subsequent consumer. P Responsible citizens should in my view have a choice. We all talk of scandalised citizens who have lost confidence in food safety. By regulating additives in feedingstuffs consistently we can help significantly to restore confidence. I too therefore can hardly wait to hear what you have to say to our proposed amendments. P Consequently we too shall also vote to reserve our right to refer the proposal back to committee if need be. SPEAKER ID 102 LANGUAGE DE NAME Kindermann Mr President this proposal to amend the 1970 DATE directive on additives in feedingstuffs is the first ORDINAL in a whole series of proposals on the subject of feedingstuffs. In other words we shall be discussing other proposals here in Parliament ORG over the next few months DATE . That this subject is of paramount importance is borne out by the huge public attention which the dioxin antibiotic sludge and other scandals have attracted. In other words this is an important facet of public health protection which is why we believe that Article 152 LAW should be taken as the legal base not Article 37 LAW as proposed by the Commission. P The amendment which the Commission ORG has proposed namely equal treatment for additives authorised before or after 31 December 1987 DATE is uncontested and has our full support. However the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development ORG has voted unanimously on some important amendments to the Commission ORG proposal. P The regulation proposed by the Commission conceals the danger of creating a marketing monopoly for certain additives. Only companies which obtained the original authorisation will have the right to apply and companies which obtained authorisation at a later date will be excluded. This sort of monopoly which could lead for example to an increase in the price of feedingstuffs should be prevented by granting provisional authorisation to all companies which had marketed a specific substance by 1 April 1998 DATE . This would then apply until the re assessment procedure has been completed. P The most important amendment to the Commission proposal is the inclusion as recommended by the rapporteur of genetically modified organisms in the directive on additives taking the compromise negotiated between Parliament ORG and the Commission on authorisation for GMOs outside the scope of the release directive as the starting point. This already gives us a basis for the authorisation of GMOs. It is therefore only logical that we make provision for genetically modified feedingstuff additives in this case just as we have in regulations already passed in other areas such as forest reproductive material to mention just one CARDINAL example. P The labelling of genetically modified additives is particularly important in this respect. On the one hand it enables farmers to make an informed decision as to whether or not they wish to use such feedingstuffs and on the other hand it enables consumers to avoid foodstuffs produced using GMOs. P Finally our group should like once again to thank the rapporteur who has gone to a great deal of trouble. I think that we can all hardly wait to hear Mr Byrne s PERSON reply. SPEAKER ID 103 CARDINAL LANGUAGE SV NAME Paulsen Mr President the report deals mainly with formalities in other words the manner in which additives will be authorised. It is less concerned with the types of additives and how they work. P I should like to take this opportunity to stress how important it is that in future all the directives are dealt with under Article 152 LAW since both food safety and environmental issues require a coherent policy and a comprehensive overview. We cannot carry on as we have done up until now that is to say dealing with each detail on its own often only after the harm has already been done. P The rapporteur places the emphasis on the testing and labelling of GMOs in feed additives. However I should like once again to raise the issue of antibiotics. Certainly five CARDINAL of the nine CARDINAL antibiotics that were originally permitted in animal feed have now been banned. It is nevertheless extremely important to ban the remaining four CARDINAL both in the interests of human health and for the sake of the animals themselves. P We now know that resistance to antibiotics poses a very serious threat to people s health particularly in the case of small children. A number of Member States are already able to show conclusively that improper practices in connection with the keeping of livestock are totally unnecessary. Several countries phased out antibiotics in animal feedingstuffs a long time ago and others are in the process of successfully doing the same. P We talk a great deal about the precautionary principle but in the case of antibiotics it has long since been forgotten. However there is another environmental principle at stake namely the exchange principle. I should like to say a few words about coccidiostats. They are a zootechnical product which is not totally necessary. There is a substitute which is used to vaccinate chickens. Although it is a little more expensive it does not harm the environment. Coccidiostats now accompany the manure that is spread on the fields. In that way they end up in our water supplies which as we all know are our most vital resource. SPEAKER ID 104 CARDINAL NAME Auroi Mr President Commissioner ladies and gentlemen the report on additives in animal feedingstuffs concerns the technical and economic problem of restoring the competitive balance between different additives in feedingstuffs and between producers of these additives. Yet after the serious dioxin crisis which affected Belgium GPE and other European NORP countries last summer DATE we cannot just view this issue in terms of competition. You may recall even though this passed virtually unnoticed by the general public that the Commission s scientific experts discovered industrial residues of dioxin loaded chemical lime in the pulp of citrus fruit imported from Brazil GPE . We must therefore closely examine all the elements of the chain involved in the manufacture of feedingstuffs for production animals. Incidentally it is ironic that the problem is much less serious for the feedingstuffs of our dogs cats and other domestic animals. Is it because of cut throat and globalised competition that industrialists have allowed this sector to become a way of recycling all the waste from the agri foodstuffs industry? P Such a serious issue cannot be limited to a technical debate even though it is the directive itself which limits the authorisation of antibiotics and other growth promoters. The precautions which we are preparing to take in respect of feedingstuffs must also be applied to the food for the very farm animals which reach our plates. As forcefully underlined by this report labelling is an absolute necessity so that each farmer on his holding is aware of all the ingredients in the feed which he is giving his livestock. He must also know whether his bag of protein granules includes GMOs as these components could represent a risk to public health. In any case the precautionary principle requires these products to be clearly traceable at all stages of their marketing. P However before labelling we need clear rules. Straight questions must be asked about the real end use of animal meal for example. Although we are looking at all the problems caused by these products in ethical and health terms it is their use which must be questioned today DATE . In this respect the chapter of the White Paper on food safety which deals with feedingstuffs must serve as a working basis for going beyond mere commercial questions. The Commission ORG has on many occasions used the farm to table example which our colleague in the PPE Group ORG has just underlined. This is a good idea but it must be made to be meaningful and to do this the problems linked to animals and those linked to consumer health must be dealt with at the same time. P This is why it is essential to approve Amendment No 2 to Recital 4 which avoids the risks of the monopoly which would arise if companies which were the first ORDINAL to be authorised to place an additive on the market were to remain the only ones able to continue marketing it during the re evaluation procedure. Also Amendments Nos 4 and 5 to the new Article 2a must be approved as these will ensure that genetically modified additives are clearly identified as such thus allowing users to make fully informed decisions. SPEAKER ID 105 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DE NAME Fiebiger Mr President because of the availability of high technology additives in the feedingstuffs industry detailed information on their use is needed from the actors and as we know there are a lot of them so that we can put a stop to practices which infringe Community ORG law. This directive on additives in feedingstuffs cannot achieve this on its own. Other directives will follow and I believe that the Committee on Agriculture ORG is well placed to deal with them. P Up the point at which meat milk bread and other products are sold over the shop counter feedingstuffs and additives are structured mixed blended cut and transported several times. The fight by feedingstuff manufacturers to gain maximum market shares causes a lot of problems just as it does in the foodstuffs industry. The negative consequences are well known the positive ones less so. I am firmly convinced that the most sensible way of protecting the health of European NORP citizens in the ecological chain is through the production of feedingstuffs in the region for the region. However more work is needed on this. SPEAKER ID 106 CARDINAL NAME Hyland Mr President may I commence by congratulating the rapporteur Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf NORP on his report. It reflects the views and concerns of all EU ORG citizens in the area of food safety and quality. P The events of the past couple of years DATE have certainly created an awareness and concern about the real threat to food safety and public health. The swift action taken by this Parliament ORG must be seen by all citizens as their greatest guarantee for the future for you have set an agenda on food quality to which Member States must conform. But even in this crucial area of administration Parliament ORG reflects its commitment to subsidiarity by encouraging Member States to take on and to face up to their responsibility. If we pursue this agenda with commitment and diligence the early years DATE of the new millennium will be a milestone in the implementation of policies that are people focused and very much reflect community needs. P I welcome in particular the proposed new and strict authorisation procedures for additives in animal feeds. Those found in breach of them must be dealt with severely. I compliment the new Commissioner responsible for food safety Mr Byrne PERSON . He has an onerous undertaking but he has responded quickly and effectively to the requirements of this House ORG as well as to the concern of consumers. I am particularly pleased that my own country Ireland GPE is to the forefront in the implementation of new food regulations based on the principle of traceability. This will make the island of Ireland GPE the centre of excellence in the future for food production. SPEAKER ID 107 NAME Daul Mr President Commissioner I too congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work. I am particularly pleased about the unanimity shown on this issue within the group. P It is therefore specified that through the adoption of a regulation the Commission will replace the existing authorisations with authorisations linked to the person responsible for putting the additives into circulation. This will occur at the same time for all the additives in question. A coherent legal framework must be re established. As of October 1999 the Commission DATE proposed introducing a legal basis into Directive 70 524 DATE EEC for the replacement of the authorisations. However we must ensure that competition distortions are not created as highlighted by Mr Kindermann and Mrs Auroi. The consumer must remain free to make a fully informed decision. P This proposal has no financial consequences for the Community ORG budget. There must therefore be total transparency for producers and consumers in the area of food safety. I am sure that the Commission can accept the report which as you know was approved unanimously in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development ORG . SPEAKER ID 108 LANGUAGE DE NAME Roth Behrendt PERSON Mr President we have said in this House ORG time and again since the BSE ORG crisis that feedingstuffs are one CARDINAL of the first ORDINAL and most important factors in safe food production and in consumer health and protection. We therefore welcome the Commission ORG s proposal on additives in feedingstuffs. P The Committee ORG on behalf of which I am speaking namely the Committee on the Environment Public Health ORG and Consumer Protection ORG decided in December DATE on the assumption that the chairman of the Committee on Agriculture ORG would draft such a good report that we could waive our opinion. P Nevertheless I should like to say a few words on the report and express a view on a number of points. First ORDINAL perhaps I should say something on the question of the legal base. Even if we have new Rules of Procedure in Parliament ORG and it may well be that with such an ambitious chairman in the Committee on Agriculture ORG problems of legislative competence will arise more and more frequently between the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on the Environment one ORG thing is always crystal clear for me in this sort of conflict cohesion in this Parliament ORG is crucial and the legal basis of a question is crucial as far as I am concerned. P Therefore and I must address this comment to you Mr Byrne I reject your choice of legal basis. If it is merely a hand me down legal basis taken over from previous directives then it is a mistake to keep it. The Treaty of Amsterdam GPE states quite clearly that where people s health is concerned Article 152 LAW is the correct legal base and may I say to our own Committee on Legal Affairs ORG and the Internal Market ORG that it is simply not good enough to look at the Commission ORG s proposal and say there is nothing in it about health and consumer protection so it has nothing to do with health and consumer protection. My group as Mr Kindermann ORG has already said will therefore vote tomorrow DATE to change the legal base and I hope that other groups in this House ORG will do likewise. P Mr Byrne I ask you to accept and agree to the change of legal basis for the sake of transparency and good cooperation. If we do not change it and we follow the Legal Affairs Committee ORG we shall be opening the floodgates to manipulation. The Commission would be able to determine the choice of legal basis by excluding any reference to health policy and we would suddenly find ourselves up against an Article 37 LAW . P Allow me to comment briefly on two CARDINAL other points. First ORDINAL genetically modified micro organisms in feedingstuffs. We cannot just refer to vertical legislation and say that at some point we will need another law. We do not have another law at the moment and until we do we must deal with genetically modified micro organisms as and when we pass legislation we must include them as an add on and insist that they be labelled. The rapporteur has done just that and that is a good sign. P I say now as I have said on numerous occasions in the past yes I too would like the Commission to propose a positive list which we can then debate and deal with in this House ORG but we do at least need a starting point for a positive list of additives in feedingstuffs. P It is equally important to have strict hygiene requirements for the manufacture of additives and for proper controls to be carried out in the Member States. There are serious shortcomings in both areas and we have a great deal of work to do yet. SPEAKER ID 109 CARDINAL NAME Nicholson Mr ORG President I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his report. This is an issue that we will no doubt be reconsidering on a number of occasions in the future. What has happened in recent years DATE has brought to our attention the tremendous problems facing not only to the producers of food but also the consumers. We must strike a balance between them. We must resolve this issue because it is important that consumers should regain confidence in the food they eat. P One CARDINAL way to achieve this is to have total transparency as far as food labelling is concerned. GMOs are the new challenge facing us. This is something that people are very worried about and quite rightly so I myself share these concerns. But I think we should not allow our concerns about GMOs to overshadow our concerns about growth promoters used in animal feed or antibiotics used in compound feed. Indeed we should not allow GMOs to obscure the fact that meat and bonemeal are still included in animal feeds in many countries in Europe LOC . One CARDINAL factor behind these developments that has been referred to in this debate is competition competition between Member States on the cost of the production of food. These are all areas in which we have to ensure a level playing field food must be of the same standard in all Member States. P We have had the dioxin scare BSE ORG and many other problems. The main problem is a financial one namely who bears the cost? The problem is that the cost is not shared equally between the consumer and the producer the producer has been forced to bear all the cost. We need an equitable distribution of the extra cost that has been incurred. We must also ensure that the food that is imported into the European Union ORG meets the standards within the European Union ORG . If we do not maintain those standards for imported food then we are going to encounter greater difficulties in the future. SPEAKER ID 110 CARDINAL NAME Byrne PERSON . I should first ORDINAL like to thank the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development ORG and its rapporteur the committee chairman Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf NORP for examining the Commission ORG s proposal. P The Commission proposal is as some of you have said rather technical. Nonetheless it has a relatively simple objective to harmonise procedures governing the authorisation of feed additives. At present there is a difference in treatment between authorisations depending on whether applications were submitted before or after 1 January 1988 DATE . The purpose of the Commission ORG s proposal is to harmonise procedures to ensure that no such difference exists. The scope of the proposed amendment is therefore very limited. P Five CARDINAL amendments have been presented by Parliament ORG . I regret that the Commission is not in a position to accept these amendments despite the fact that I am fully aware of the views and commitment of Parliament the Agricultural Committee ORG and in particular the rapporteur Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf NORP on these issues. P I shall deal with each of the individual amendments separately. The first ORDINAL amendment proposes to change the legal base of the proposal by replacing Article 37 LAW with Article 152 LAW . I would simply point out that the Commission proposal makes no reference to health or consumer protection. The proposed amendment is technical and cannot be interpreted as having as its primary objective the protection of public health. I note that Parliament s Committee ORG on Legal Affairs ORG and the Internal Market ORG also accepts that Article 37 LAW is the appropriate legal base. I remind Parliament ORG that in Article 152 LAW the primary objective is the protection of health. I commend to you the arguments set out in the letter from the Legal Affairs Committee ORG which sets out the position in my view with precision clarity and commendable brevity. P Amendments Nos 2 and 3 go much further than the Commission proposal since they aim to introduce additional provisions on genetically modified additives. I am the first ORDINAL to accept that GMOs are a very important issue. I also accept and acknowledge that a number of initiatives to update EU ORG legislation in the field of GMOs are necessary. However this technical amendment is not the correct instrument to introduce such initiatives. The Commission is of the view that it is premature to amend the rules currently laid down by Directive 70 524 CARDINAL on genetically modified additives at this stage. Instead it is appropriate to await developments in relation to the common position on the amendment to Directive 90 CARDINAL 220 which is currently in second ORDINAL reading in Parliament ORG . The Commission envisages going much further than is currently proposed by Parliament ORG in its amendments. P I can also assure Parliament ORG that I will ensure that the pertinent provisions of Directive 90 220 ORG are included in the proposal for a recasting of Directive 70 524 CARDINAL that the Commission ORG has proposed in the White Paper on food safety to present to Parliament ORG before July 2001 DATE . I can also assure Parliament ORG that all observations made here today DATE will be fully taken into account. P Amendments Nos 4 and 5 are also unacceptable because they give undue preference to copy products by granting them authorisation to be placed into circulation even before an application for authorisation has been submitted. The Commission insists on first ORDINAL evaluating such applications as to their safety and efficacy before giving authorisations. I can only ask you again to bear in mind the technical nature of the Commission proposal and to wait for the substantive proposal for a new directive on additives in feedingstuffs to address wider issues. P I should just like to deal with some of the specific issues that were raised during the debate. First ORDINAL of all regarding the observations made by Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf I wish to assure him that we will change the procedure for authorisation of GMO ORG additives in the Additives Directive 70 524 and not in the Novel Feed Directive. This is a directive that deals more specifically with raw materials rather than with additives. P The text taken by Parliament ORG is from the Directive which was adopted in 1998 DATE . But the vertical legislation in Directive 90 CARDINAL 220 on how to carry out the environmental risk assessment of GMOs has changed since then and is still changing. It is before Parliament ORG for second ORDINAL reading. It is my belief that we should await the final outcome of Directive 90 ORG 220 and in particular Article 11 LAW . P Reference was also made to the question of whether this proposal could give rise to the risk of the establishment of monopolies. Mr Kindermann and Mrs Auroi PERSON made reference to this. There are just a few points I should like to make on that issue. P First ORDINAL of all this matter has been in the pipeline since 1993 DATE so it has not really been sprung on any other commodity producers. Indeed any such applicants can still apply in respect of their particular product. I should also stress that the Commission ORG has never approved any application for an authorisation for GMOs to be included in additives. P Mrs Roth Behrendt made reference to the question of the appropriate legal base whether it should be Article 37 or Article 152 LAW . I again refer to what I said earlier in relation to this and assure her and the House ORG that it would be entirely inappropriate for the Commission to seek to justify any measure based on Article 37 LAW merely by excluding from the provision any reference to public health. This is an issue that has been looked at on at least two CARDINAL separate occasions by the European Court of Justice ORG which has laid down the legal criteria for situations such as this where the appropriate legal base has to be properly taken into account when putting forward legislation. The jurisprudence of the Court ORG appears to be quite clear in relation to this. As an overall comment to the suggested amendments here particularly in relation to the legal base issue it would be inappropriate in my opinion to change the legal base to Article 152 LAW in these circumstances as it would be very likely to fall foul of the objective criteria that have been laid down by the Court ORG . P A number of you made reference Mr Nicholson PERSON in particular to the issue surrounding labelling. Directive 70 CARDINAL 524 foresees the issue of labelling in the genetic modification of additives. It is already included now indication of the particular characteristics due to the manufacturing products . So this issue will be addressed. That formula enabled us to oblige applicants to put on the label the fact that genetic modification techniques have been used in the product the subject matter of the application. But we do reserve the right when you propose to amend a directive or a regulation to look at the whole regulation and not just the part which you have singled out. SPEAKER ID 115 LANGUAGE DE NAME B ge Mr President Commissioner ladies and gentlemen it was and always will be one of life s mysteries one of the unsolved riddles of the follow up to the BSE ORG crisis that we still have no Community rules for the control of scrapie in sheep. In this respect the Commission ORG s proposals to amend directive 91 68 DATE and delete the reference to scrapie and the report by Mrs Roth Behrendt PERSON on the detection and control of TSE ORG infections in general comply with Parliament ORG s demands in the wake of the follow up report by the BSE ORG committee of inquiry and we expressly welcome this. P I should however like to add that no new scientific knowledge was needed which proved that the experimental infection of sheep by feeding them BSE ORG infected feed produced a clinical expression of the disease which is indistinguishable from the symptoms of scrapie. No new knowledge was needed because the theory from the beginning was that BSE ORG and scrapie must be related and this theory has increasingly taken hold. From this point of view we are slightly behind the times. P I am therefore in complete agreement with the Commission ORG s proposal on scrapie. I should however like to add that it only makes sense if we ensure that the new TSE ORG regulation allows a reasonable symbiosis between consumer protection and practicable suggestions. We therefore need to take consistent account of six CARDINAL or seven CARDINAL points in the coming debate on the TSE ORG proposal and that of course includes scrapie. P When we discuss the TSE ORG regulation Commissioner we must also clarify that we shortly intend to discuss separate proposals under Article 152 LAW as the corresponding legal base for products excluded from this regulation such as cosmetics medicinal products or animal feed. We insist on this. As far as I am concerned that means that fundamental core provisions in this proposed regulation must not be relegated yet again to the Annex but included in the body of the proposed regulation because we here in Parliament ORG want to and will assume joint responsibility here. It also means that when we are fighting these diseases the problem of destroying whole herds in the event of an outbreak of scrapie or BSE ORG and the question of defining geographical areas are items which also remain on the agenda. P Although I welcome the fact that the fight against scrapie is included in the TSE ORG regulation I feel that the Commission ORG s proposals for fighting scrapie are still not consistent enough and I shall submit amendments on behalf of the Committee for Agriculture and Rural Development ORG to tighten up the proposals when the Roth Behrendt PERSON report is debated. P I should also like to address two CARDINAL other points. We expressly welcome the regional classification of the status of Member States as regards outbreaks of scrapie or TSEs. Here again the Commission is increasing its response to the work carried out by and the demands made by Parliament ORG . P Finally in discussing the question of the future application of tests we should of course bear in mind that we have still not reached the point where tests are generally applicable. But the tests available now are perfectly able to guarantee security in consumer health policy albeit not for every individual animal. But when we need to consider if a region can move from a negative epidemiological status to a better category an epidemiological inspection of the situation in a region in the form of suitable sampling in abattoirs using such tests can provide useful pointers in the political and scientific debate as to where there is a need for preventive consumer protection and basically where such tests can be used to help us settle disputes on a proper basis. P I would be grateful Commissioner if you would take these passing comments on board in the report on scrapie and in the general report on the fight against TSEs and bear in mind that we shall be calling you to account on these points. P SPEAKER ID 116 LANGUAGE DE NAME Roth Behrendt PERSON Mr President over the years DATE the following situation has arisen one CARDINAL subject has developed into a subject of many facets. You are lucky that Mr B ge s report only deals with this on the sidelines with my report you will have to justify yourself more thoroughly and you will have more trouble doing so. P Finally just one CARDINAL more brief comment Mr Byrne PERSON . We have a new Commission. Whether or not we will agree with the work carried out by this Commission and the President of the Commission ORG only time will tell. They belong in the legislative text. I might do the same if I were a Commissioner because I could simply change an annex under a comitology procedure and I would not always need to work with Parliament ORG which takes so long and is so difficult. But you must understand that we cannot let you get away with this. In other words whenever I get the chance I shall take everything out of the annexes and cram it into the legislative text. And you would be well advised to do likewise from the outset. P SPEAKER ID 117 LANGUAGE DE NAME Schierhuber Mr President Commissioner I should like to remind you of the composition of our food chain and how important it is for this chain to provide us with safe healthy food which is produced as a matter of principle without any questionable or risky interim or end products. P Over recent years DATE these basic principles have often been neglected in animal husbandry and in epidemiological matters because of shoddy practice or greed. The European Parliament ORG has already taken a clear stand on BSE ORG and I think that we should do likewise on all epidemics in animals. We should not allow food safety to be compromised because in the final analysis it is our health which is at stake. P The Commission ORG s proposal encompasses both the transportation and the placing on the market of sheep and goats and a Community ORG regulation to fight scrapie. This is even more important given that there is no clear proof that BSE ORG and scrapie are unrelated. Animals are bought throughout Europe LOC and transported over the entire continent. The spread of an epidemic as the result of bringing in one sick animal can have huge consequences for farmers. And I should point out that for the first ORDINAL time in history a case of scrapie was detected in Austria GPE about four weeks ago DATE . P Scrapie PERSON is a particularly insidious disease because the pathogen can remain active in dust for years DATE and is then ingested in food. The disease is always fatal. As there is no vaccination farmers can only protect themselves by not buying animals from countries in which there are cases of scrapie. Even if scrapie cannot be passed on to human beings the connection with BSE ORG has still not been clarified as I have already said. As a farmer myself I am most concerned that consumer health should not be put at risk. P I am in favour of preventive measures starting with feeding which is suitable for the species rather than measures to combat an epidemic once it has broken out. I therefore welcome the Commission ORG s initiative to create a new legal base for combating scrapie. SPEAKER ID 119 NAME Nicholson PERSON Mr President I too would like to offer my congratulations to the rapporteur. No one would want to see what happened to farmers with BSE ORG happen ever again. We have to bring in the most stringent rules and we have to make them work. I do not want to point the finger at any particular country but many countries are now facing similar problems to those we have had in the United Kingdom GPE . It will be there for some time to come. We have to ensure that the whole system of traceability of following the animal from birth until slaughter and right through the whole food chain is part of that confidence building mechanism. If we are not able to achieve that then we will have tremendous trouble in the future.
