It was never the responsibility of the farmer it was the food compounders who caused this problem and we have to ensure that it never happens again. SPEAKER ID 120 CARDINAL NAME Byrne PERSON . Mr President I am pleased to have been given this opportunity to discuss a subject where there is good cooperation between Parliament ORG and the Commission namely combating TSEs. I should also like to thank Mr B ge for his work on this issue. P Considerable progress has been made on our proposal for a European Parliament ORG and Council ORG regulation under Article 152 of the Treaty LAW on the prevention and control of TSEs ORG . This proposal addresses all TSE ORG risk in all animals at all stages of the production chain. I am here today to listen to your opinions on the first ORDINAL step in this process of establishing a truly comprehensive Community ORG system for the control of these diseases. I have proposed in the proposal at hand to delete all currently existing Community ORG rules on scrapie in sheep and goats and to transpose them to the framework proposal for a regulation. The detailed rules would then follow in that framework proposal. P I have been informed that you welcome this initiative as appears from your contributions this afternoon TIME to formulate a single text. I am looking forward to discussing any further improvements you might wish to suggest under the framework proposal for the legislation especially after the reference made by Mrs Roth Behrendt PERSON to her own report and opinion on this issue. I look forward to receipt of that document which will be taken into account in all further considerations in relation to this issue. P Finally I would say this in relation to the observation about including legislation in annexes and the observation that we must achieve an effective balance between Parliament ORG having a full say and yet at the same time our having speedy resolutions speedy legislation and speedy amendments to existing legislation. In the months DATE I have been Commissioner and observed the way legislation goes through the system I can see that much work needs to be done on this issue so that we can all achieve what we seek to achieve that is the translation of policy into legislation. SPEAKER ID 121 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you Commissioner. P The debate is closed. P The vote will take place tomorrow DATE at 11.30 a.m. TIME CHAPTER PERSON ID 8 Community ORG policy in the field of water SPEAKER ID 122 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is the recommendation for second ORDINAL reading A5 0027 2000 on the common position adopted by the Council ORG with a view to the adoption of a European Parliament ORG and Council ORG directive on establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy 9085 CARDINAL 3 1999 C5 0209 1999 1997 0067 COD Rapporteur Mrs Lienemann . SPEAKER ID 123 CARDINAL NAME Lienemann FR PERSON Mr President Commissioners ladies and gentlemen water will be one of the main environmental and world issues of the twenty first century DATE . Climate change global resources river quality and groundwater aquifer quality are major challenges which threaten our common future. We will either be able to restore water quality to suit the planet s ecosystem or we will experience a whole range of adverse events which will threaten the development of certain regions the living conditions of the inhabitants of other regions and even more fundamentally the global balance. P To support this statement I would point to an excellent report drafted by our colleague M rio Soares in the international bodies on the state of the seas and oceans. When talking about climate change we have rightly referred to the greenhouse effect and the state of the atmosphere. Yet we also know that the deterioration of the oceans will significantly destabilise whole areas of our planet. P Europe LOC must therefore lead by example to some extent both because it must promote a certain development model and because it is itself facing serious problems of pollution and deterioration of its waters including its groundwater surface waters and seas. P Furthermore Europe LOC has signed international conventions in particular the OSPAR Convention EVENT in which it made certain commitments. In this it said that in a few years DATE time we must have stopped dumping pollution and halted the increase of pollution and we must have reached a near zero CARDINAL level of toxic and dangerous substances. Despite having signed these international agreements this directive and the specific policies in the field reveal that Europe LOC cannot achieve the objectives set or must defer these for so long that the very credibility of its signature of these international conventions is threatened. This is why in the debate on the framework directive on water policy the European Parliament ORG has since the first ORDINAL reading demanded coherence between the framework directive and the international objectives particularly with regard to respect for OSPAR ORG . This convergence must be effective and specific and must commit us to action. P The European Union ORG s water policy is not starting from zero CARDINAL . Many directives have already been adopted. Furthermore the Commission wants to make these directives more understandable and more compatible with each other and to give them clearer objectives. The preparation of this framework directive is therefore prompted by a desire for rationalisation. However at first reading this House ORG insisted that the current directive should not only be compatible with the commitments made like OSPAR ORG but should allow us to reverse the course of affairs. For despite these directives and frequent declarations about the effort which must be made in terms of water protection when we look at the state of the environment in Europe LOC we can see that the objectives have not been achieved. In many cases the situation has deteriorated and we therefore cannot settle for just rationalisation of the texts. P We must set objectives which are equal to the challenges facing us. Yet we do not have much time. We could as the Commission ORG has proposed accept these overlong deadlines which the Commission ORG and the Council ORG have extended even further. Yet if we do we will not only have a credibility problem with the general public but these efforts will be postponed until tomorrow DATE and then tomorrow they will be deferred again. It is clear that in this event the objectives will never be achieved. P I am stressing this point because when disasters are being reported daily DATE in the news we cannot just keep on saying for the umpteenth time that Europe LOC did not act when it should have done. Then in our haste we act as if we will solve the problems which we refused to tackle properly at the appropriate time. The current example of the Danube and the pollution from Rumania GPE shows very clearly that if we fail to establish a new method of economic development clear requirements controls and precise measures concerning the state of our rivers this type of incident will not only occur again but will do so increasingly over time. It is also clear that if we do nothing our agriculture will continue to develop in a very unbalanced manner. Even now the rivers in Brittany PERSON are eutrophying and this is damaging tourism. P To conclude the issues are clear at this second ORDINAL reading. Do we or do we not want standards compatible with OSPAR in other words to get dangerous substances down to zero CARDINAL ? Do we want to shorten the deadlines proposed by the Council ORG for this directive? Do we want to have a pricing policy which enables all public and private participants to clean up and save water? Do we seriously want to respond to the hopes of our peoples? The majority of the amendments approved by the Committee on the Environment Public Health ORG and Consumer Protection meet these objectives. I hope they will be supported by this House ORG . SPEAKER ID 124 LANGUAGE DE NAME Schleicher Mr President ladies and gentlemen Mrs Lienemann PERSON has just painted a very drastic picture of how important water and air are to us especially as the very source of life for human beings. The problem is one of both water quality and water resources of which there is not a plentiful supply everywhere in Europe LOC especially in very dry regions. I am sorry that Commissioner Wallstr PERSON m who is responsible in this area cannot be here now because this is after all a very very important directive on which the Commission ORG has been working for a long time and water protection legislation which we are debating now at second ORDINAL reading affects all the citizens of the European Union ORG as well as all the people in countries wishing to join who will have to comply with EU ORG legislation once they accede. P We have been working on this subject for ten years DATE and a comprehensive approach was only made possible as the result of a hearing arranged and held by the Committee on the Environment Public Health ORG and Consumer Policy in 1994 DATE . A great deal of work has been carried out between then and this second reading by numerous Members of the European Parliament the European Commission ORG and the Council of Ministers ORG . We reduced the 243 CARDINAL proposed amendments in the Environment Committee ORG to 77 CARDINAL but another 30 CARDINAL have been added. You see there are numerous matters of concern here and they are all very different. Some want tighter legislation some want more clarification others want to serve national interests. Even within my group the Group of the European People s Party ORG Christian Democrats NORP and European Democrats NORP there were of course differences of opinion. Our line is to work towards realistic objectives and practicable solutions. In this sense the proposed amendments tabled by me and other members on behalf of the group represent an improvement on the demands set out in the common position. Some proposed amendments which we support should strengthen the European Parliament ORG s negotiating position in the forthcoming conciliation with the Council of Ministers ORG . P We obviously reject all unrealistic demands which affect the European NORP Parliament ORG s credibility. For me that includes the zero CARDINAL demand i.e. the demand for zero CARDINAL inputs up to 2020 DATE . That would sound the death knell for every agricultural and many industrial undertakings. I should like to stress quite particularly here that we have already made considerable progress under current national and European NORP water protection laws however imperfect they are and however little they are complied with in the Member States. I only need to remind you that we again have salmon in the Rhine GPE which would have been unthinkable 20 years ago DATE and that salmon are due to be released this spring DATE in the Elbe which was particularly polluted. P That does not mean that we do not still have huge efforts to make in order to improve water protection yet further and maintain the quality of water and ground water and this will doubtless cost a great deal of money. Farmers have voiced a number of concerns over the past few days DATE . You can only farm if you have an adequate supply of clean water. The line followed by our group for the negotiations with the Council of Ministers ORG will allow an acceptable solution to be found for farmers too. P I am horrified that both Members of Parliament ORG and the public have been misled by false arguments in this difficult and sometimes highly technical matter. I therefore extend my special thanks to my colleagues in the group who helped us find compromises. I also extend my special thanks to our rapporteur Mrs Lienemann PERSON for all her work and her cooperative attitude even if we have agreed to differ on certain points. And I also thank the representatives of the European Commission ORG who stood by with advice and expert help at all times. If the representatives of the Council of Ministers ORG take an equally constructive approach then I have no doubt that together we shall find an even better solution to the problem of water protection in Europe LOC under the conciliation procedure. SPEAKER ID 125 LANGUAGE ES NAME Sornosa Mart ORG nez Mr President I would firstly like to congratulate Mrs Lienemann PERSON on the excellent work which she has presented and on her efforts in terms of overcoming the differences between us with regard to water. P The framework directive on water is a necessary initiative. Nevertheless given that the idea of solidarity is central to the process of European NORP construction this directive must take into account the fact that water resources should be seen as a factor in social cohesion. P Nobody doubts that water is a resource of interest to all of us. However in Spain GPE and the other southern countries which have an unusual climate the management of water resources require political action in order to rationalise their use and other cooperative measures. Therefore we believe that this framework directive should advocate a use of water which allows us to overcome territorial imbalances and to this end I ask that you support Amendment No 95 which has been presented by our group. We wish to ensure that Article 1 of the LAW directive promotes the sustainable efficient fair and considerate use of water. P I am now going to briefly discuss the main issues on which the Spanish NORP Socialist delegation differs somewhat from certain positions which have been expressed here. P One CARDINAL example is water transfers. We would prefer the future framework directive not to subject the implementation of transfers to Community supervision. We consider that given the hydrological characteristics of Spain GPE where transfers of a structural nature are carried out the authorities of the country should make decisions with regard to its own resources and these decisions should of course always be taken in accordance with the quest for cohesion and the rational use of water. P With regard to one of the most controversial points of our debate the application of tariffs the Spanish NORP Socialists have been arguing in accordance with the principle that the polluter should pay that the directive should propose policies on accessible prices for all levels of consumption. In Spain GPE a policy of full recuperation of water costs would clearly not have the same effect as in the countries of the centre and north of Europe LOC . The Spanish NORP would see an increase in the price of water for its different uses owing to the scarcity of water resources and the internalisation of the environmental costs which will have to be met within the framework of the provisions of the directive. P We have therefore always argued for a progressive system of recuperation of costs. This system should take good account of social environmental and economic effects and its implementation should be modulated in accordance with differing geographical and climatic conditions. P We want to build a Europe LOC with a sustainable and healthy environment. However an environmental Europe LOC cannot in any circumstances be built at different speeds but must be built from a point of view of solidarity ORG . SPEAKER ID 126 CARDINAL NAME Davies Mr President the ecological disaster in the Danube reminds us of how closely linked all the countries of Europe LOC are and how important water is to us all. Discharges from chemical factories in my own constituency in the north west of England GPE will end up on the beaches of mainland Europe LOC . This brings home the connections which bind us together. P This framework directive is intended to paint the broad brushstrokes of the policy for the next decades DATE and there has been much panic over the details. It is important for us to remember that this is a framework. These brushstrokes are indeed very broad. It is easy for individual countries for individual sectors of industry to escape the effects which have been painted to us in recent days DATE . There are many opportunities to hide. The reality is that the details of this legislation will be set out in daughter directives in months DATE and years DATE to come. That is the time to debate some of these problems of detail. The broad principles are surely ones we should be able to accept the broad principles that we wish to reduce hazardous waste leaking into the groundwater the broad principles that we should be aiming to ensure that chemicals which we all need in society in all circumstances should not be finding their way into our water system. P There is a chemical factory in the north west LOC which wrote to me to say that we must vote against this legislation. I would have to ask them what chemicals they are putting into the water supply at the moment and why they are not broadcasting to all the residents in that area exactly what they are doing. This is something that they prefer to avoid doing. P The principle also concerns water charging. The basic understanding which many of us now share is that we need to introduce environmental taxation to encourage conservation to use the carrot and stick approach to make best use of our assets so that we do not add to the pollution or loss of a valuable resource like water. P I want to refer to the political position here. The common position has weakened the stand taken by Parliament ORG at first ORDINAL reading. Some of the NGOs would say that the directive as now framed is worse than useless. It is a retrograde step. This is an opportunity for us to improve the situation. We need to get ourselves into a position of conciliation. We have seen vote after vote lost. Measure after measure has come out of the Environment Committee ORG . We have failed to achieve a qualified majority. Our attempt to improve the environment of Europe LOC has failed. We need to get into that conciliation position. We need at the end of the day DATE to ensure that we end up with a sensible balanced policy of real improvements at a reasonable cost. SPEAKER ID 127 LANGUAGE NL NAME De Roo PERSON Mr President ladies and gentlemen as long as nearly thirty years ago DATE the European Commission ORG made attempts to draw up a European NORP water policy. A hundred and twenty nine CARDINAL chemical substances had to be regulated. Eventually standards were drawn up for only a dozen CARDINAL or so substances. P The unanimity principle was at the root of this debacle. Some seven years ago DATE it still looked like the European NORP water policy was going to be sacrificed on the altar of subsidiarity. The conservative government leaders Messrs Major ORG and Kohl PERSON decided in a cosy fireside chat at the Edinburgh Summit ORG that it was totally unnecessary for the Spanish NORP to receive drinking water supplies which were as good as those of the Germans NORP or English LANGUAGE . P This sentiment is partly reflected in the common position which came about under British Socialist ORG Presidency. That position is like holey cheese or to keep it the sphere of water as leaky as a sieve. It explains the ground swell of amendments which were tabled by the Committee on the Environment ORG nearly one hundred CARDINAL amendments for the second ORDINAL reading. This is unusual but most of these amendments are desperately needed to plug the holes. The dangerous chemical substances constitute a big leak. The chemical industry and unfortunately the European Commission ORG and the Council of Ministers ORG too want to draft a separate risk analysis for each dangerous substance. This is very time consuming and more importantly there is no acceptable level of pollution for dangerous chemical substances. Only the background level of the ocean is acceptable. This is what is meant by the term close to zero CARDINAL . P The Commission already has a list of 32 CARDINAL priority substances many of which have a hormone deregulating effect. These are so called endocrine disrupters and cause even in extremely minimal quantities changes in the gender of animals and even humans as is more and more being ascertained by scientists. This is why it is so important that the European Parliament ORG declares itself openly in favour of the OSPAR ORG objective of close to zero CARDINAL by the year 2020 DATE . P I would like to mention two CARDINAL substances from the Commission ORG s list mercury and tributyl abbreviated to TBT. On the bottom of the Wadden Sea LOC the values of mercury and TBT ORG are higher than the OSPAR ORG value to wit ten and one thousand DATE times respectively. The chemical industry and society as a whole have to learn to replace these dangerous chemical substances by harmless substitutes and if this is impossible to apply them in closed systems. For the substance TBT this means that it can no longer be used as an anti fouling substance. A sound alternative would be to clean the ship s sides mechanically. P I would like to finish off by expressing the hope that the European Parliament ORG will pick up once again its green image and will argue in favour of the close to zero CARDINAL option for dangerous chemical and hormone deregulating substances by the year 2020 DATE . SPEAKER ID 128 LANGUAGE SV NAME Sj stedt Mr President the European Parliament ORG has a crucial role to play in the development of the Water Directive ORG . The Council ORG s common position is totally inadequate in a number of areas. Therefore our task is to make the requirements in the directive tighter and more concrete. As members of the Confederal Group ORG of the European United Left Nordic Green Left ORG we regarded certain principles as particularly important when we adopted a position on the different proposals. P Firstly ORDINAL we think that the time frame for implementing the proposed measures should be shorter than that proposed by the Council ORG . We therefore support the proposal to reduce the time allotted for implementing different parts of the directive. P Secondly I should like the phasing out of noxious materials to be carried out consistently. There should be no initial delay to allow new evaluation criteria to be developed before the measures are implemented. The legislation should also have written into it the fact that the international conventions such as the OSPAR Convention EVENT must be respected. P Thirdly ORDINAL we should like a clear statement regarding the pricing policy. This means that the basic principle must be that the price should represent the real cost of the water used. Nowadays taxpayers often have to subsidise industry and farming. The obvious point of departure for legislation should be that polluters or consumers pay although exemptions would be permitted in extreme cases. P Fourthly ORDINAL we should like exemptions from the rules on water status to be kept to a minimum and clearly defined. P Fifthly the protection of groundwater status and measures against persistent pollution of the groundwater should be transparent and clear. P Against that background our group is able to vote in favour of most of the amendments tabled by Mrs Lienemann PERSON the rapporteur ORG as adopted in committee. We should like to see the scope of a couple of points extended. We will therefore vote for the Greens Amendments Nos 102 103 ORG and 104 which we consider to be improvements on the present position. P As regards pricing policy there are sometimes extreme cases which may require derogations from the principles laid down in the report. My own view is that the options for allowing derogations had already been given proper attention in Amendment No 43 tabled by the committee and been even more clearly set out in the Greens Amendment LAW No 105. I cannot see any need for other derogations besides those specified in the two CARDINAL amendments just mentioned. However some people in our political group think otherwise. Consequently Amendment No 107 on the same question has been tabled by one CARDINAL section of our group only. P On the whole I welcome the committee s proposals set out in Mrs Lienemann s PERSON report and think they could provide a good basis for a hard won compromise. SPEAKER ID 129 CARDINAL NAME Thomas Mauro PERSON Mr President every satellite photo proves that we do indeed live on the blue planet yet the abundance of water is an illusion. P The recent disaster on the Danube NORP serves as a reminder that our rivers are the lifelines of our planet and that pollution does not respect borders. Water is a renewable but limited natural resource. It becomes scarcer when it is mismanaged and when the geographical and climatic conditions are unfavourable. P In the EU ORG this is a crucial issue in the Mediterranean LOC region and also in other European NORP countries where we are witnessing the gradual drying of wet areas. The increase in vulnerable areas both wet and dry inequalities between countries inequalities between different regions within countries and unusual climatic economic geographical and geological events are all the evidence we need. However these must not lead to competition distortions within the Community ORG . We have therefore tabled amendments to highlight the importance of the special relationship between agriculture and water given that water is an essential factor in the occupation and development of the land. P Agricultural needs are clearly much greater in the south and this specific point must be taken into account in the framework directive. It is not only in the Member States that solutions to these problems are being sought. Last October DATE in Turin GPE the countries in the Euro Mediterranean Partnership EVENT bluntly demanded a Marshall PERSON plan for water for the south coast of the Mediterranean LOC . We are not fortunately at this point. P However we are in Europe LOC experiencing droughts and desertification in certain regions and also floods which the directive underlines. For example France GPE the Rhine GPE valley and central Europe LOC recently suffered flooding. We need this framework directive as an essential element of a sustainable development policy which must make the various uses of water compatible with each other. Yet we also need to integrate the protection and conservation of biodiversity into this new management of water. The water issue will definitely not be settled today DATE . In fact the problems of enlargement and climate change will offer new prospects. SPEAKER ID 130 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL NAME Blokland Mr President it is very likely that during this century DATE good quality water will be of even more strategic importance than oil. This is enough reason to thank Mrs Lienemann PERSON for the efforts she has made to obtain sound surface water. P It seems rather complicated to attain a proper European NORP legislative framework. With the framework directive on water policy we are hoping to end the fragmentation of the EU ORG s water legislation. But that has not dismissed us from the task of drawing up an extensive and complicated directive which will require great care in its implementation from the executive bodies. More specifically the possibilities for adopting a specific policy by Member States and water boards which have been set up thanks to the catchment basin approach need to be maximised. P The key goals remain the prevention from further pollution of ground and surface water the protection of eco systems the promotion of the sustainable use of water the control of floods and droughts and the termination of discharging dangerous substances into surface water. P As far as the discharge of these dangerous substances is concerned I am of the opinion that the Councils objectives lack both commitment and ambition. The Committee on the Environment s ORG present proposal to reduce discharges to close to zero CARDINAL is in my view to be welcomed and worthy of emulation. However a great deal of attention must be paid to its viability. Consideration must then be given to natural background emissions which cannot be influenced as well as diffused emissions which are difficult to control and which pollute the water quite substantially. SPEAKER ID 131 LANGUAGE DE NAME Kronberger Mr President we need to get used to the idea in the 21st century DATE that we have to show water a completely new respect. In the 20th century DATE water was merely a free evacuation and disposal system for poisonous substances special waste chemicals and so on. And we can already see the consequences! P We need to rethink and recognise that water is our most important asset and that our responsibility towards it goes far beyond the present generation. The directive must be negotiated accordingly and our citizens must be able to understand what we or rather what the Commission is planning here. P In the final analysis water protection is not just a social question it is a decisive social question which is why the polluter pays principle must be applied more rigorously as otherwise we all bear the consequences. Given the advanced state of pollution of water resources it is important not just to maintain the status quo but to ensure during the vote tomorrow DATE that we achieve genuine quality improvements. SPEAKER ID 132 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL NAME Oomen Ruijten Mr President it must be some six years ago DATE now that Mr Karl Heinz Florenz PERSON assisted by Mrs Ursula Schleicher put in a request and managed to overhaul the water policy in its entirety. It is not an easy topic and in my opinion the efforts made by Mrs Lienemann PERSON are very laudable indeed. P The decision making process concerning this framework directive on water has reached a crucial stage. The topic has been brought under the codecision procedure and as a result we have been able to draft important more stringent legislation as early on as at first ORDINAL reading. In fact the common position which was issued at the end of last year DATE was already a major improvement on the original proposal. It is also very hard to adopt policy in this respect because the discrepancies are so huge. I would also address the Spanish NORP Member in this respect in the North of Europe LOC we often face floods but also polluted water from industry whilst the problem facing the Members in the South LOC is often related to transporting water over long distances simply to supply drinking water or water for agriculture. P I would like to enter into the two CARDINAL elements of this topic in more detail. I would first ORDINAL of all like to focus on quality. The Netherlands GPE is significantly affected by the European NORP water policy. A very important component to wit one third CARDINAL of our drinking water is extracted from surface water in the Netherlands GPE . The Netherlands GPE is located downstream in a delta which means that the quality of the surface water which heads our way is of key importance. P Another important point of discussion is the standardisation of water quality. In a number of amendments the proposed standards and especially the OSPAR ORG standard for 2020 DATE are called into question. Although I understand that according to some this standard is unclear or that it cannot be defended judicially I do believe that we have to support it because we could then provide more precise standards in a conciliation procedure. P I would now like to say a few words on quantity management. In his poem Herinneringen aan Holland Reminiscing FAC about Holland GPE a famous Dutch NORP poet mentioned water too which with its never ending trail of destruction was feared and respected. In 1953 DATE we suffered an enormous flood at a time when we were able to play a pioneering role in terms of dam technology. When our rivers flooded in 1990 DATE we established that installing artificial works upstream affects the water storage capacity downstream and can cause a great deal of damage. P This means that in terms of quantity management too we need to put in considerable effort to ensure that life upstream and downstream is not affected by it. SPEAKER ID 133 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL NAME Corbey Mr President I too would like to start by congratulating Mrs Lienemann PERSON on her excellent work. P Water is a basic necessity of life and a fundamental right. Everyone should have clean water at their disposal but the availability and good quality of water is not so self evident as many have experienced in Southern Europe LOC and are experiencing now in the Danube NORP countries too. P Water is often a source of conflict between countries and peoples. This is why it is important that water becomes subject to international coordination. We need to recognise that water is a joint liability. Cooperation within a catchment basin must be self evident. Too little operational capacity upstream or in fact excessive use can cause problems downstream. Coordination is the key word here. P The problem of water is becoming increasingly topical. Changes in the climate and minor rises in temperature have a direct impact on precipitation. Some areas are becoming drier whilst many are becoming wetter. It is time for action. P In March DATE the Second World Water Forum EVENT will be held in The Hague GPE . This Forum stands for a worldwide vision. This vision must translate into regional action plans for sustainable water management and water control. P The time for action is upon us. The European Parliament ORG must now opt for a sustainable water policy as a starting point and remain realistic at the same time. But we should not lower our standards too much either. The common position is not ambitious enough. This is why it is necessary to refer to previous international agreements or the OSPAR ORG objectives. We need to aim for dangerous substances to be phased out by 2020 DATE . This has been agreed for the marine environment and it is obvious that this agreement will also apply to other waters too. P The OSPAR ORG objectives are now being drawn up. A list has been compiled containing 400 CARDINAL substances which produce clear risks for the environment. It is both technically and economically possible to reduce the emission of these substances to virtually zero CARDINAL and we need to opt for this once again. P Needless to say the directive also needs to be binding. Countries downstream must be able to count on the fact that countries upstream meet the quality objectives. Quality has a price but pollution could well have a much higher price tag in future. It is therefore strategically important that responsibility for water is established. It is also important for the different watercourses to be kept together and managed as the totality they in fact are irrespective of who owns one CARDINAL section or another of a common watercourse. SPEAKER ID 135 CARDINAL LANGUAGE DE NAME Breyer Ladies and gentlemen the proposal for a directive does indeed as many speakers have already said represent an historic chance to simplify and improve the jumble of piecemeal EU ORG regulations and directives and achieve a high level of environmental protection in Europe LOC . However I have the impression that the policy in the water framework directive is geared towards deregulation and renationalisation. I also hope that the vote will not be a washout and that will depend on what I see as two CARDINAL quite fundamental points. P First OSPAR. We know that the Commission proposal does not go far enough unfortunately this also applies to the proposal by the Committee on the Environment ORG . Merely pulling proposals out of the air is not enough. What we need is a completely legally binding objective for OSPAR ORG . Only then will we manage to achieve legal clarity and more importantly objectives which are enforceable under the law. Anything else will fall short of the mark and will not help to prevent ecological disasters such as those which have just come to light in Romania GPE and Hungary GPE from happening to us. P I find it unfortunate that national governments are not prepared to stand up for legally binding protection despite having agreed internationally on OSPAR ORG . But I think that this is exactly what we have to make up for here in Parliament ORG in order to demonstrate that we will not allow the credibility of our policy to be lost or compromised. P It is also important to reinforce the polluter pays principle because prices must speak the ecological truth. We must not bow down before the agricultural or chemical industry lobbyists on the contrary we must use our vote to promote and express that fact that we want the polluter pays principle and hence cost covering prices. Water is our most important resource and we must use our vote to ensure that the incentives and pressure are there to really comply with the OSPAR ORG convention. With closed production circuits this is possible anything else would water down the directive. Let us grab our chance. SPEAKER ID 136 CARDINAL LANGUAGE ES NAME Gonz lez lvarez Mr President in the small amount of time allotted to me I would like to welcome the Mrs Lienemann s PERSON report and remind the House ORG of three CARDINAL principles to which all other principles must be subordinate which are clearly expressed in the rapporteur s amendments water is not a commercial product but the property of all the peoples of the Union the ultimate objective is to eliminate all pollutants in surface water and groundwater and to inform the public so that it can participate in the recuperation of water and not use water excessively given that it is such a precious commodity. P I know that this directive may have problems given the differing situations of the various countries of the Union as has already been mentioned. The situation in the north is different from that in the south and different from the situation in those countries which have the problem of desert areas. I understand this. However there are some amendments which attempt to help the countries of the south specifically Amendment No 43 which with regard to the recuperation of costs also indicates that Member States must take into account the social and environmental conditions of the countries when it comes to decision making. P There are also difficulties with the issue of transfers. In my country I live in the north of Spain GPE there is a considerable difference between the north and the south and difficulties arise when we have to transfer water from one CARDINAL place to another. However Mrs Lienemann s PERSON report also says that the river basins receiving the transferred water must save and protect their water. P I know that this is a difficult report and that the differing situations of countries cause difficulties but we must move forward with a framework directive which will prevent a repetition of what is happening on the Danube and what happened in Do ana. We cannot allow our European NORP water to be polluted Mr President and we must produce a directive which will strengthen the political will of governments to preserve the resource of water which is so precious to all of us. SPEAKER ID 137 CARDINAL NAME Fitzsimons Mr President my compliments to the rapporteur on a splendid report. As an Irish NORP Member of the European Parliament ORG coming from a country which has large reserves of rich water I support the vast majority of the proposals included in this directive. However I would now like to look at the areas of difference between Parliament s Committee ORG on the Environment and the Council. The latter has already brought forward its common position on this matter. P According to the Council ORG the objective of achieving good surface water status should be secured no later than 16 years DATE after the directive enters into force whereas Parliament s Committee ORG on the Environment would like to see this deadline shortened to ten years DATE . I see no reason why European Union ORG Member States cannot work to implement the key provisions of this directive in as short a time as possible. P I now turn to the amendments to be tabled before Parliament ORG tomorrow concerning the principle of the recovery of cost of water usage. The Council ORG in its common position states that the European Union ORG governments must take account of the principle of recovery of the cost of water usage. No specific target date for the implementation of this principle was included in the common position. P Amendment No 43 seeks to ensure that by the year 2010 DATE water pricing policies in Europe LOC must provide adequate incentives to use water efficiently. Moreover an adequate contribution from different economic sectors broken down into industrial household and agricultural sectors must ensure that this policy is implemented. Unless these amendments are supported tomorrow DATE a strong message will be sent out that metering and water rates should be implemented for households right across the European Union ORG states. This is politically impractical from an Irish NORP perspective as indeed it would be from the perspective of other EU ORG Member States such as Portugal GPE Greece GPE and Spain GPE . SPEAKER ID 138 LANGUAGE DA NAME Sandb k Mr President I want first ORDINAL of all to say thank you to Mrs Lienemann PERSON for her report. It is here and now that we decide to what extent the EU ORG countries are to work effectively for a cleaner aquatic environment in the years DATE to come. We can do this by as a Parliament ORG amending the Council ORG s common position and showing the way forward in working for a cleaner environment. In its unaltered form the present directive could in fact have very unfortunate and long term consequences for the environment and for our drinking water. It would be to send out the wrong signals both to European NORP industry and to the European NORP people. It is crucial to adhere to a limit upon total discharges of chemicals into our waters. The directive quite obviously provides too extended a time frame within which time is to be spent measuring every single one of the approximately 100 000 chemicals in circulation. We cannot afford to wait. In this connection I would ask Parliament ORG to support Amendment No 108 in which the words water pollution caused by individual pollutants are replaced by prevention of water pollution through the continuous reduction in discharges . We cannot delay environmental work by going into inordinate detail rather than working on reducing total discharges of hazardous substances into the environment. The EU ORG s Ministers for the Environment must therefore stand by their affiliation to the OSPAR Convention which now already defines what is hazardous to the environment. This Convention should be our guide in working for the clean environment which we owe to ourselves and not least to our descendants. SPEAKER ID 139 LANGUAGE IT NAME Fiori Mr President it is difficult to summarise the areas covered by such a large and complex directive. P The Treaty of Amsterdam WORK_OF_ART reiterates the priority criteria for prevention for the implementation of the polluter pays principle and for sustainable development through an environmental impact assessment. P Clearly the importance of recognising the economic value of ecological factors in setting prices and making operators accountable through the adoption of incentives for non polluting systems seems unquestionable in the light of events that characterise the relationship between economic development and the protection of our environmental heritage particularly our water resources. P This situation is loudly echoed in many sectors of the economy and especially in the agricultural sector. The concept of good agricultural practice has been introduced in amongst the complexity of the current relationships between agriculture environment and water resources and between positive and negative effects and amongst the wide range of local realities and production systems and so on. This concept indicates which agricultural production method to use in order to satisfy the Community expectation of an environmental protection of water resources that surpasses basic standards along with the subsequent costs and reductions in income. P The obligation to develop and consolidate a strategy for integration derives from this notion with the aim of keeping the management of water resources at the heart of the sustainable economic production model in the light of current conditions. P We must not with this in mind pursue a strategy of separating the objective of preventing a deterioration in the state of surface water and groundwater from the objectives of protecting improving and restoring their quality as this would create a superfluous hierarchy of priorities detrimental to the overall functioning of interventions and specific measures that target a combined approach and the use of the best available techniques. P As regards eliminating the pollution generated by dangerous substances in the aquatic environment an optimum approach should provide a regulation at both national and Community ORG levels which enables clearer identification of the various classes of bodies of water polluted as a result of human production activities. P Finally we need to set up a system which prepares an objective list of potentially dangerous substances using the increased information available on their chemical physical and biological properties in such a way as to create an integrated model for intervention at a range of strategic levels in order to protect our water heritage which is fundamental to us all. SPEAKER ID 140 LANGUAGE DE NAME Lange Mr President Commissioner ladies and gentlemen if we are to take the principle of sustainability enshrined in the Treaty of Amsterdam GPE seriously then our long term objective must be to achieve zero CARDINAL inputs in our water because we need to safeguard water so that future generations do not pay the price for our water consumption. We can achieve this long term objective by developing measures with demanding standards. In this respect I fully support the amendments proposed by Mrs Lienemann PERSON to develop a reasonable approach using quality standards so that we can eventually say that when people use water they are not consuming it but maintaining present stocks. P This directive contains a number of very positive elements which are worth highlighting. First ORDINAL there is wide information for and involvement by the public a rarity in a European NORP directive. Secondly ORDINAL there is compulsory cooperation. I am glad a holistic approach to water is being taken here and that authorities in the individual national states and beyond the borders of the national states are at last obliged to work together and ensure that water is of a high quality. P Thirdly ORG I should like to address the question of the timetable. I am firmly convinced that we need a strict tight timetable in order to work towards our long term objective. Compare it with what happens in December DATE . We all know in December DATE that Christmas Eve falls on 24th December DATE and we start buying presents. But what would we do if we knew in December DATE that Christmas DATE was in thirty years DATE time. We all know what we would do which is why we need a tight timetable for our water policy. I emphatically support the rapporteur ORG s proposals and think that we need a tight timetable for all areas of the directive from the list of measures to the question of employment measures. SPEAKER ID 141 LANGUAGE DA NAME Busk Mr President the purpose of the present objective ought to be to ensure that the Member States work together to protect groundwater drinking water and surface water and that the level of protection corresponds to existing EU ORG environmental legislation. May I take this opportunity to remind you that previous resolutions concerning the Nitrates Directive have still not been implemented in all Member States in spite of the fact that there is a common EU ORG resolution. The present proposal tightens up the protection of the aquatic environment in a number of ways which exceed our current environmental objectives. It is proposed that a target should be achieved for concentrations in the aquatic environment which is close to the background values for naturally occurring substances and close to zero for humanly produced synthetic substances. This cannot be done and it also in any case goes against nature. Adopting this report would have serious consequences for agriculture in the EU ORG if concentrations of for example phosphorus and nitrogen could not exceed the background values for these substances in the aquatic environment and if a limit of zero CARDINAL were to be established for pesticides in the aquatic environment. European NORP agriculture would not for example be able to grow bread grain with a high enough protein content for it to be used for making bread. As a result agricultural production would move to other countries outside the EU ORG with consequent high socio economic and employment costs. I cannot vote in favour of the sections in the Water Framework Directive ORG which deal with these states of affairs. SPEAKER ID 142 LANGUAGE NL NAME Staes Mr PERSON President ladies and gentlemen water is a precious raw material. Millions CARDINAL of people do not even have clean water a absolute necessity for survival at their disposal. It should therefore not surprise us that water is the cause of wars. The capitalist world too sends out its pawns in order to gain maximum control over water reservoirs. General interest or solidarity often do not come into the equation. P Europe LOC is therefore facing an arduous task that of combining a Community ORG water policy which is fragmented in terms of objectives and means into more coherent framework legislation. I have to admit that in Flanders ORG where I come from we still have a long way to go too. We were recently rapped on the knuckles by the Commission ORG regarding this matter. Anyone with any sense would like to see this framework directive used as a big stick for those pursuing policies who are now failing in some way. P The common position is in this respect a farce a document with no strings attached and a true affront in the light of the OSPAR ORG agreements. The period of implementation can even be extended up to 34 years DATE . By then my children will be older than I am now. You have to admit this is a joke. Tomorrow DATE we might opt in favour of a weak and permissive framework which ruins the future of our children. Either we opt for the amendments of my group of the rapporteur or the Committee on the Environment ORG . P I would like to finish off with this observation. In the past couple of months DATE we have witnessed a great deal of lobbying in Belgium GPE . What was remarkable about this dossier was the enormous pressure from the Council of Ministers ORG . In our own country this pressure was exerted by both Flemish NORP and Wallonian Environment ORG administrations. They have opted for the weak common position in favour of our Parliament ORG s more drastic positioning. I really do wonder whether this is an approach of which the green Environment Ministers in my country are aware. P Ladies and gentlemen fine words are no longer sufficient. We need to change tack completely. During the vote tomorrow DATE we can make it clear that Europe LOC is drafting a responsible and future orientated water policy. This can only benefit our credibility. SPEAKER ID 143 CARDINAL NAME President The debate is suspended and will resume at 9 p.m. TIME CHAPTER ID 9 CARDINAL The dialogue on Europe LOC institutional reform SPEAKER ID 144 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is the Commission communication The dialogue on Europe LOC institutional reform the issues at stake. SPEAKER ID 145 CARDINAL NAME Barnier Mr President ladies and gentlemen the Commission is discussing this issue right now but it will be very surprising if its work is completed today DATE . I am basically here to speak to you as indicated by your agenda on a new initiative which the Commission is proposing as just one of its responses to the major challenge of institutional reform. This reform must involve all the actors in European NORP construction with yourselves as MEPs at the forefront but also myself as a Commissioner the Council ministers and national MPs. It must also involve the officials who work in our various institutions and who are committed to and motivated by this European NORP construction. P This morning TIME in the lengthy debate which I attended with Mr Prodi many of you mentioned the lack of democracy and remoteness of the European NORP institutions. Yet it is not just a question of who does what as one of you said very clearly and forcefully. Ensuring that our citizens understand who does what in our various institutions is the very least we can do. We must also now explain what we are doing together and what we want to do together in the future particularly with the countries which will be joining us. P We too are concerned about this lack of democracy and the Commission has therefore decided to launch the Dialogue on Europe LOC in order to play its part in this direct contact with the people. This initiative will be launched on the day DATE after the opening of the Intergovernmental Conference ORG . During the IGC I will have the honour of representing the Commission together with Mr Prodi and of working closely with your two CARDINAL representatives Mr Brok and Mr Tsatsos. All the Commissioners have undertaken to use some of their time when they go to any country or region and not just their own which in my case happens three or four CARDINAL times a month to engage in direct dialogue with the public and not just with the lite or those in power whom we meet as a matter of course. We also plan to establish direct contacts in universities schools and factories to meet the people answer their questions and listen to them. In this way we will play our part as will you in making the necessary effort and meeting the urgent obligation to reduce the democratic deficit and the remoteness of our citizens from what we do. P We hope to conduct this initiative in cooperation with the Member States and in conjunction with the European Parliament ORG . We will produce a regular summary of this initiative so that public opinion can be measured and we can adjust or reorient the work. We also hope to conduct this initiative in consultation with the national parliaments local elected representatives non governmental organisations socio professional organisations and the media. Opinion multipliers political groups and parties MEPs and national MPs elected representatives as I have just said local authorities or national parliaments the Committee of the Regions the Economic and Social Committee ORG organisations stemming from civil society and university and education circles will all be involved. P Need I remind you that the European Parliament ORG itself took the initiative on 1 February DATE ? I must again thank Mr Napolitano PERSON for organising an initial working meeting with the representatives of the national parliaments who are of course the representatives of the people in each Member State. The Commission will propose that the Member States become involved in this exercise either as part of ad hoc cooperation or a more structured partnership. We are setting up a media plan and close contacts with the European Union ORG Presidency and the European Parliament ORG . I have indicated the conditions under which the Commissioners will play their part through public meetings and visits. We want to encourage debate among the people. P Without presuming to lecture you God forbid or even advise you may I just point out that when it was my honour to be Minister for European Affairs in my own country I saw the need to establish a direct dialogue with the people? Each week when engaging in this dialogue in each region I realised that there was a real need for the European Union ORG to have a face. I therefore took a European NORP Commissioner and not just the French NORP ones or ambassadors posted in Paris GPE or MEPs to engage in this dialogue each week DATE . This made me realise that people had many intelligent questions and that they needed to be respected listened to and informed. So this is what we are going to do. We will have a budget of approximately EUR 4 million MONEY for 2000 DATE which you will hopefully approve. Financing from the 2001 DATE budget must also be negotiated as we want this initiative not just to be an experiment but to last throughout both 2000 DATE and 2001 DATE . It will therefore be ongoing throughout the negotiation of the Intergovernmental Conference and the ratification process. P We will launch this dialogue on 8 March DATE in Brussels GPE in the presence of 700 CARDINAL young Commission stagiaires. Your President Mrs Fontaine PERSON has agreed to take part with Mr Prodi and several Commissioners in this initial dialogue. I can assure you that whenever a Commissioner intends to engage in dialogue the most immediately available MEPs will also be able to take part in order to give their point of view and explain the work and role of the European Parliament ORG . P That is all I have to say for the moment. I welcome any questions suggestions or proposals from the Members present. SPEAKER ID 146 CARDINAL NAME President Colleagues you know the rules. You are expected to ask questions not necessarily make lengthy statements. You have one minute TIME each in which to ask your question. SPEAKER ID 150 CARDINAL NAME Barnier Mr Dupuis PERSON first ORDINAL of all I attach a great deal of importance in my public life to the word citizen . It is one of the most wonderful words in a democracy and must be used. We will conduct this dialogue with our citizens including the most disadvantaged and those isolated from decision making or information centres. P With regard to the IGC ORG and this issue of the fight against fraud and specifically fraud against the Community ORG budget and interests we have retained the idea in our proposals of creating a new and specific post of a European NORP public prosecutor. We have done this in the spirit of this House ORG s work and perhaps by going down the same road. This public prosecutor would have the authority recognised by the EU Treaty ORG and therefore by the Member States GPE to investigate thoroughly any case threatening the Community ORG budget and interests. P We can clearly and almost clinically see that legal cooperation is now no longer enough to fight against this fraud whether it originates from inside or outside the Community ORG . This is why we have proposed the creation of a European NORP public prosecutor who could having investigated a case from start to finish then have this investigated and ruled on by the most appropriate national court. P In reply to your second ORDINAL point on the Court of Justice ORG we have not yet established our position on the Court of Justice ORG because we were waiting for the Dur PERSON report which was published a few days ago DATE . SPEAKER ID 151 LANGUAGE DA NAME Haarder Mr President Mr Commissioner the day before DATE yesterday there was a leading news item in the most popular Danish NORP news programme which I would ask you to comment on. The story went that an official in the Commission had apparently told an Austrian NORP businessman that because he was Austrian NORP he would possibly be excluded from being able to participate in a scientific development project together with businesses in other countries including Denmark GPE . I would ask you to confirm that if an official has said that an Austrian NORP company is in some way excluded from participating in joint development projects then this official has got the wrong end of the stick and that if he has not said this then there is no story. Will you confirm what is the case? SPEAKER ID 152 CARDINAL NAME Barnier Mr Haarder to my knowledge no official has been authorised to say such a thing. My personal opinion is that it would be wrong and unfair to penalise the Austrian NORP people businesses and employees because of concerns prompted by the establishment in Austria GPE of a new government coalition. Therefore subject to verification which I or someone else will give immediately after this sitting I can confirm what you have just said that the Commission ORG has never said or authorised anything of this sort. P Generally speaking there are other lessons to be learnt from what is happening in Austria GPE . I have myself suggested various possible responses to this challenge which serves to remind us all once more what we have been doing together since 1957 DATE . This is an economic community of course but it is also primarily a community of values. This is why we are drawing up a Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART which will more widely and more clearly protect our citizens on an individual basis. This is why we have Article 13 of the EC Treaty LAW on discrimination which we proposed in our opinion of 26 January DATE even before the Austrian NORP crisis should be applied after the IGC ORG by qualified majority rather than by unanimity. This is why I personally have an idea to supplement Article 7 of the EU Treaty LAW with a new paragraph which would give the democratic warning or monitoring procedure a legal basis. Finally this is why we have public debate. The only way to eliminate misconceived ideas is to offer alternatives which brings me back to the subject of our discussion. I firmly believe in the democratic force and value of debate particularly to fight against demagoguery. SPEAKER ID 162 CARDINAL NAME Barnier Yes Mr Bonde we will be starting this debate with 700 CARDINAL young people in Brussels GPE who are going to be working in the institutions and with the Commission. I believe that it will be good to start this dialogue with young people who are motivated. P In terms of social protection I can confirm that we have made proposals about qualified majority or unanimous voting but these are regardless of ideology. In your country Mr Bonde like everywhere else I believe people are keen for the internal market to work properly under the fairest conditions of competition and movement of goods and people. This will therefore be our rule. We are proposing that decisions on certain policies or measures involving taxation or social protection and social security should be taken by qualified majority voting when there is a direct link with the proper operation of the internal market. Our proposal is not general or systematic. I am well aware of the sensitivity of these taxation and social protection issues. I do not believe that all the national systems of social protection should be made identical. This has never been the case. We are simply trying to ensure in a Europe LOC with 30 CARDINAL or 27 CARDINAL Member States the best conditions for the operation of the internal market without one country being able to block the other 26 CARDINAL or 27 CARDINAL . P Mr MacCormick I agree that this dialogue must reach beyond the national capitals. It must get as close as possible to the people where they live and where they have their roots. If I said anything different I would be contradicting myself as Commissioner for Regional Policy which is one of the most specific and most visible policies for increasing employment and improving the quality of life of people in their regions. You will often hear me say that this policy does not just have one main objective of achieving cohesion and solidarity between the regions but that it is intended in addition to help people where they live to preserve their roots traditions soul and identity. We will therefore conduct this dialogue with the towns and regions. P Mr Berthu the Helsinki GPE mandate is clear and we are working within this. It specifies that we must deal firstly and as a priority with the three CARDINAL basic issues which were left out in Amsterdam GPE . It also adds related institutional questions and issues which may be included in the negotiations depending on the Portuguese NORP and French NORP presidencies. The Commission ORG is acting correctly if on a particular point it believes it must add to its opinion which covers many institutional questions. I am not yet sure that we will do this on Article 7 LAW . However if we do this will not be solely in response or as a reaction to an economic situation which is sufficiently serious that the fourteen CARDINAL governments of the Union must mobilise together to give their response. We will also do this with regard for the future in general. P We will use all the means available to permanently strengthen the community of values which we have been building together since the founding of the Union in 1957 DATE and even before that on the rubble of the Second World War EVENT . Everything which can be done will be useful. I am sure that you and I Mr Berthu NORP can at least agree on this. SPEAKER ID 163 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you Commissioner. You have answered the questions precisely and also opened the dialogue for Europe LOC that you referred to. You have set a very good example of time keeping today DATE . P That concludes the debate. CHAPTER ID 10 Question Time Commission ORG SPEAKER ID 164 CARDINAL NAME President The next item is Question Time B5 0009 2000 . We will examine questions to the Commission. P First ORDINAL part SPEAKER ID 165 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 166 CARDINAL NAME Anna Karamanou PERSON Question No 36 by H 0025 ORG 00 P Subject High infant mortality in Kosovo GPE According to the latest UN ORG data received from the World Health Organisation Kosovo ORG has the highest rate of infant mortality in Europe LOC almost 50 CARDINAL of babies born prematurely die while the war has produced a steep rise in miscarriages and children who manage to go to term are smaller than the norm. In the context of the humanitarian aid provided by the Union and the efforts of its envoy Bernard Kouchner PERSON will the Commission say what measures have been taken to safeguard the women of Kosovo GPE s right to motherhood and the health of pregnant women women in childbirth and babies? SPEAKER ID 167 CARDINAL NAME Patten Mr President the Commission is conscious of the very difficult situation concerning health and health facilities in Kosovo GPE not just for pregnant women but across the board. This results both from the recent conflict and from the years DATE of neglect and lack of maintenance that preceded it. P The statistics quoted on child mortality speak for themselves and are wholly unacceptable. However the situation is hardly better for other parts of the population. The Commission ORG s response has been as follows firstly the health sector has been a significant beneficiary of ECHO ORG funding. ECHO ORG is currently focusing on the provision of medical supplies and emergency health care on support to institutions as well as vaccination. However efforts are increasingly oriented towards the establishment of a self sufficient healthcare system in the province. UNMIK ORG has already taken a significant role in this field. P Secondly ORDINAL under the reconstruction programme urgent intervention at the hospital in Mitrovica GPE has already been initiated with a EUR 1 million rehabilitation programme. Progress is slow due to the tense relations between the ethnic groups of this divided city. However the Commission is maintaining its efforts with the support of UNMIK ORG for this project. We hope that one day it may become a symbol promoting the benefits of ethnic reconciliation. Under the European Community ORG s damage assessment estimated costs of the reconstruction of healthcare facilities and provision of equipment to dispensaries and health houses amount to EUR 4 million MONEY . The Commission is now turning to the programming of 2000 funds. We expect to dedicate a considerable sum to improving the healthcare system. The emphasis will be on long term reforms covering health financing as well as training and procurement. Work is already under way with UNMIK to determine an appropriate contribution from the Commission to this enterprise. SPEAKER ID 168 CARDINAL LANGUAGE EL NAME Karamanou Commissioner this morning TIME President Prodi PERSON among others stressed that the Balkans LOC are testing our ability to act effectively the very credibility of the European Union ORG is on trial and the gap between words and deeds must finally be closed. P Commissioner do you really think that the facts we have about high infant mortality in Kosovo GPE the highest in Europe LOC and more generally the picture of human misery and destruction that prevails in Kosovo GPE are not already damaging our credibility and casting doubt on our ability to live up to our promises? Besides Commissioner is so called humanitarian military intervention justified by the present picture of human destruction in Kosovo GPE ? Do you think that so much inaction is excusable when on the continent of Europe LOC itself the right to life is at risk? SPEAKER ID 169 CARDINAL NAME Patten I do not think that our reconstruction agency or the task force before it which have been working incredibly hard in Kosovo GPE would regard it as an adequate description of their labours to suggest that they had been standing idly by. I am sure the honourable Member did not mean that. P Of course she is entirely correct in saying that the Union s credibility is on the line with what happens not just in Kosovo GPE but in the Balkans LOC as a whole. I am very concerned that the assistance we provide should arrive expeditiously and in a way which can maximise our assistance. P I would just make two CARDINAL points about the situation in Kosovo GPE which we are addressing as enthusiastically as we can along WHO lines. First ORDINAL of all I am sure that the honourable Member recognises that over the period of the 1990s DATE the government in Belgrade GPE underfunded the health service in Kosovo GPE and many Albanians NORP found that they were not really receiving any health care at all. As a result of that a parallel health care system was put in place through the Mother Teresa Society ORG . So what we are dealing with is not just the consequences of conflict but the consequences of years of neglect and chronic under investment. P Secondly ORDINAL and I am sure that the honourable Member recognises this as well some of the tragic stories to come out of Kosovo GPE in recent weeks DATE have not been about child mortalities during carriage of a baby but child mortality after a healthy baby has been born. Those were cases in which women who during the hostilities or before the hostilities tragically killed their own children. We are dealing with a horrific story in Kosovo GPE . We have to work as well as we can in the health care field and in others to restore something approaching civilised standards and civilised behaviour but it is not going to be easy. SPEAKER ID 183 CARDINAL NAME Rodi Kratsa Tsagaropoulou Question No 39 by H 0036 00 DATE P Subject Drafting of Charter of Fundamental Rights The general public welcomes the fact that a Charter of Fundamental Rights is to be drawn up. It is also to be hoped that it will meet the challenges of Europe LOC in the 21st century DATE . P What are the Commission ORG s views on the substance of the Charter PRODUCT ? What type of rights will the Charter PRODUCT set out economic social and cultural ? Which citizens will it cover those of the European Union ORG or the citizens of all European NORP countries with a view to enlargement? Will it cover immigrants etc.? P Will it set out established social rights in the European Union ORG or will it set a broader agenda? What means will the Charter use to ensure that it clearly guarantees equality between the sexes? What are the Commission ORG s views on incorporating the Charter into the Treaty on European Union? SPEAKER ID 184 CARDINAL NAME Vitorino Like the honourable Member the Commission welcomes the decision taken by the Heads of State and Government ORG to start the process of drawing up a European NORP Charter of Fundamental Rights. In the conclusions of the Cologne European Council the Heads of State and Government ORG even established the broad outlines of the Charter PRODUCT s content. According to these conclusions the Charter PRODUCT must contain three CARDINAL categories of rights. The first ORDINAL category is rights of freedom and equality and procedural rights as guaranteed by the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ORG . The second ORDINAL is the rights reserved for citizens of the European Union ORG . The third ORDINAL is economic and social rights as contained in the European Social Charter ORG and the Community Charter of the Fundamental Social Rights of Workers ORG insofar as they do not merely establish objectives for action by the Union. P The Commission considers that the Convention responsible for drawing up the Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART must respect the mandate given by the Cologne European Council ORG . Having said that this does not mean that the Convention should be limited to a codifying role of simply compiling the existing rights from various sources. As I have said before in this House the Commission ORG is convinced that the Convention must be able if necessary to adapt and develop these rights in view of current circumstances particularly technological and social changes. However given the mandate and the final objective of the text to be submitted to the Heads of State and Government ORG this power must be exercised with caution and on a case by case basis. P The rights conferred by this Charter PRODUCT will have at least two CARDINAL types of beneficiary. Some rights will apply to anyone present in the EU ORG territory while others will benefit only citizens of the European Union ORG . It may also be envisaged that some economic and social rights could be guaranteed only for citizens of the European Union ORG and third ORDINAL country nationals meeting certain conditions. It is not possible at this initial stage of the process of drawing up the Charter to prejudge its content in more detail. However I can confirm that the principle of equal opportunity and equal treatment between men and women will certainly be included among the rights guaranteed by the future European NORP Charter of Fundamental Rights. This is because this principle already figures among the rights guaranteed by the EC Treaty ORG and by secondary legislation and because it undoubtedly constitutes a common constitutional tradition in the Member States. P As I have also said before to this House the Commission ORG is favourable to inserting the Charter LAW in the EU Treaty ORG . However we are fully aware that the final decision on this matter will fall to the Heads of State and Government. The difficult part which will fall to the Convention ORG is therefore to draw up an ambitious and politically significant text which can be integrated as such into the Treaties. In its opinion on the holding of an Intergovernmental Conference to amend the Treaties the Commission ORG noted that the European Council ORG must decide during the year 2000 DATE on the inclusion of certain items on the IGC agenda in particular the European Charter of Fundamental Rights LAW . P SPEAKER ID 185 LANGUAGE EL NAME Kratsa Tsagaropoulou Commissioner it is quite significant that at the beginning of this new century people in Europe LOC men and women are being called upon to redefine their rights and obligations. We hope that this important Cologne Council ORG decision will become a reality. Globalisation on the one hand and enlargement on the other make it urgently necessary to define those rights. Seattle GPE is a real source of concern in that context and we hope that the European Council ORG in Nice GPE will not be a wasted meeting. But if we are to secure the public s participation in this new planning we would like to learn what plan the European NORP bodies and specifically the Commission are proposing as the social and democratic model of Europe LOC in the twenty first century DATE . I listened to your general guidelines and I would like to ask you what is the position of children as entities in their own right in the Commission ORG s plans for the new model of society in the twenty first century DATE . SPEAKER ID 186 CARDINAL NAME Vitorino Mr President Mrs Kratsa Tsagaropoulou PERSON in my opinion and as Mr Prodi said this morning TIME the drawing up of the Charter PRODUCT is an exercise with great political significance. This is because it shows that the Union places the fundamental rights of citizens at the top of the political concerns for the future of our common project. P In this context the criteria by which these rights are to be chosen must be clearly indicated. The essential criterion is the rights of citizens with regard to the European NORP institutions as contained in the European NORP project enshrined in the Treaties of the European Union ORG . P I understand your concern about the rights of children. Many elements of our work and particularly of my work as Commissioner for Justice ORG and Home Affairs ORG involve protecting the rights of children. This is an area in which the principle of subsidiarity applies fully. Each Member State is principally responsible for defining its responsibilities towards children. P As for the EU ORG s responsibility the rights of children must be recognised in the Charter according to the areas in which the Union can give added value to the promotion of the social and economic situation and even the citizenship in its broadest sense of children. P I hope we can meet the challenge which the honourable Member has posed for the Commission and the whole Convention. SPEAKER ID 187 CARDINAL NAME Martin David W Mr PERSON President I have had the privilege of hearing the Commissioner a number of times on this issue and I very much agree with his approach. However I should like to ask a slightly different question.
