SPEAKER ID 188 CARDINAL NAME Vitorino It is the policy of the Commission ORG to promote an open and wide debate on the Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART not only with non governmental organisations but also with the citizens in a project as far reaching as the Charter PRODUCT is. I can assure you that the Commission will do its best to promote the debate on the future Charter of Fundamental Rights WORK_OF_ART . P We can achieve the best of both worlds by having a clear text a text that can be easily read by the citizens and at the same time a text that can be used as a legal instrument. There is no contradiction between the two CARDINAL . The challenge we have is to bring them together in the final version of the Charter PRODUCT . I am very glad to know that I can count on your support here. SPEAKER ID 189 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 190 CARDINAL NAME Glyn Ford PERSON Question No 40 CARDINAL by H 0095 00 ORG P Subject Articles 6.1 7.1 CARDINAL and 7.2 of the Treaty on European Union ORG Article 6.1 of the Treaty states that the Union is based on principles of liberty democracy respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is clear from statements over the past years DATE that J rg Haider and the Freedom Party ORG do not respect human rights and fundamental freedoms with respect to third ORDINAL country nationals and minority groups living in Austria GPE . P Therefore will the Commission state when they intend to propose under Article 7.1 LAW that there is the existence of a serious and persistent breach by a Member State of the principles mentioned in Article 6.1 LAW . and urge the Council ORG acting by qualified majority to suspend certain rights deriving from the application of this Treaty to Austria GPE including the voting rights of the representative of Austria GPE in the Council ORG ? SPEAKER ID 191 LANGUAGE PT NAME Vitorino Mr President ladies and gentlemen I would like to begin my answer by reminding you of the position adopted by the Commission with regard to the formation of the new Austrian NORP Government. This was reiterated this morning TIME in President Romano Prodi PERSON s speech on that government which includes Ministers from J rg Haider s Freedom Party ORG . I am referring of course to the statement made by the Commission on 1 February 2000 DATE the basic elements of which I would like to restate. The Commission ORG confirmed then as it does today DATE that it shares the concerns underlying the Portuguese NORP Presidency s statement of 1 February 2000 DATE . These concerns are legitimate and there are good reasons for them. There is no need for me to remind you of J rg Haider s political bias and of his many xenophobic and racist public statements which are also anti European NORP . The fact that an openly extremist racist and xenophobic party can reach power in a Member State of the European Union ORG will inevitably be a source of concern to the other States GPE that are taking part in the European NORP project. The European Commission ORG is certainly not indifferent to the matter either. P Secondly the Commission ORG reiterated and reiterates again its commitment to continue fulfilling its duty as guardian of the Treaties specifically with regard to Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty on European Union. One CARDINAL of the most important innovations provided by the Treaty of Amsterdam GPE was to clarify the basic principles which represent the shared heritage of the Member States. Another innovation was the establishment of a mechanism which would monitor whether these principles are being fulfilled and which would react if any of them were violated. The Commission thereby gave a practical demonstration of its commitment to one of the essential pillars that of the rule of law. This principle means that the Commission must act within the limits laid down by the Treaties and it is in this context that the statement of 1 February DATE was made. The Commission is not a State ORG . It cannot and must not act as if it were one. In order to give a precise answer to your question Mr Ford ORG I must remind you that in order for the mechanism established by Article 7.1 of the Treaty on European Union LAW to be applied there must be proof of the existence and I quote of a serious and persistent breach by a Member State of the principles mentioned in Article 6 LAW . I repeat a serious and persistent breach is the condition necessary for the Commission to be able to propose to the Council ORG that measures be adopted against a Member State. I think that it is obvious that conditions have not been met which would apply to the current situation in Austria GPE . As a matter of fact I think that I am right in saying that we all hope that these conditions of a serious and persistent breach of human rights and of democracy are never fulfilled either in Austria GPE or in any other Member State. I would like to assure you of my personal commitment and of that of the Commission as stated once again by President Prodi GPE this morning TIME to doing everything to ensure that we do not have to apply the mechanism stated in Article 7 LAW . I would also like to assure you though that we will not hesitate to apply it should it prove necessary. The values at stake are too central too fundamental for us to accept dithering or compromises. P Individuals and governments should be judged by what they do rather than by what they say. In Austria GPE s case the statements are contradictory to say the least. On the one hand any of us could pick up on a whole cluster of inflammatory remarks by the leader of the Freedom Party ORG . On the other hand the new Austrian NORP Government s programme reaffirms its commitment to defend democracy and human rights. We will soon have our first ORDINAL opportunity and an excellent opportunity it will be to see which one of these two CARDINAL faces of the Freedom Party ORG is the real one. I am referring to the position the Austrian NORP Government will adopt at the Council ORG with regard to the Commission ORG s proposals for the establishment of an action programme to combat discrimination and for two CARDINAL directives. One CARDINAL applies to the principle of treating people equally without differentiating on the grounds of race or ethnic origin. The other proposal will provide protection at work against discrimination on the grounds of ethnic or racial origin religion handicap or sexual persuasion. These are significant texts adopted in accordance with Article 13 of the Treaty LAW which gave the Community ORG jurisdiction to fight discrimination on the grounds of race ethnic origin sex etc. P Lastly I would like to assure you Mr Ford that the Commission ORG will remain vigilant and will not fail to act in accordance with its responsibilities should it prove necessary. SPEAKER ID 192 CARDINAL NAME Ford I thank the Commissioner for his reply to my question. But is Commissioner Vitorino aware not only of Mr Haider s and the Freedom Party ORG s words but also of their deeds? Mr Haider PERSON has actually been in government in the southern province of Carinthia PERSON where he has led a racist and xenophobic campaign against the Slovene ORG speaking minority in that region who are Austrian NORP citizens where he has attempted to abolish dual language education and where there has been clear discrimination against the Roma ORG and immigrant communities. SPEAKER ID 193 CARDINAL NAME Vitorino It is quite clear to me that it is the responsibility of the Commission ORG to closely monitor the evolution of the situation in the Member States according to the procedures and standards that are enshrined in Article 6 LAW and justify the use of Article 7 of the Treaty LAW . Therefore I am fully confident that the Commission will be able to follow very closely the evolution of the situation in Austria GPE as in any other Member State. If any concrete case of persistent violation of human rights perpetrated by the government of one CARDINAL Member State occurs we will be entirely capable to react and to act accordingly. P I also rely not only on the cooperation of the Members of the European Parliament ORG but also on the cooperation of non governmental organisations which have always made an important contribution to the anti discrimination policy of the Commission. The protection of ethnic minorities and of minorities that speak a specific language is an element of the programme and of the two CARDINAL directives that the Commission ORG has put before the Council ORG . I sincerely hope that all Member States will take the opportunity of this action plan and these two CARDINAL directives that the Commission ORG has presented to the Council ORG to reiterate in clear and concrete terms their approval for the action plan and for the directives and their commitment to fight against discrimination racism and xenophobia wherever it might occur. SPEAKER ID 194 CARDINAL NAME President Thank you very much Mr Vitorino for your valuable contribution to this Question Time. P Second ORDINAL part P Questions to Mrs Wallstr m SPEAKER ID 195 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 196 CARDINAL NAME Paul A.A.J.G. PERSON Lannoye Question No 41 by H 0021 00 ORG P Subject Surplus electrical and electronic equipment Each year DATE the European Union ORG has to deal with a growing volume of surplus electrical and electronic equipment 6 million tonnes QUANTITY worth in 1998 DATE mainly on account of the speed with which such equipment becomes obsolescent. The environmental problems stemming from the incineration and the dumping of such waste are mainly attributable to the presence of hazardous substances lead cadmium mercury hexavalent chrome PVC and halogenated flame retarders . A preliminary draft directive intended to regulate the management of such waste has been through three CARDINAL successive versions the most recent of which dates from July 1999 DATE . P Can the Commission account for the lengthy gestation of this draft which should in theory have emerged in its final form in 1998 DATE ? Is it true that the US Government ORG is disputing most of the provisions of the current draft and is even threatening to appeal to the World Trade Organisation ORG for infringement of Article XI of the GATT ORG and Article 2 2 LAW of the Agreement on technical obstacles to trade if it is adopted? SPEAKER ID 197 LANGUAGE SV NAME Wallstr m The Commission agrees with MEPs that the current method of dumping electrical and electronic waste is causing major environmental problems. Consequently the Commission decided to prepare a proposal on the subject and since 1997 DATE has been involved in discussions with the parties concerned. The outcome of the discussions as well as of the in depth investigations which are being carried out in this area are now being examined by the Commission. Some parts of the proposal have been criticised among them the phasing out of some heavy metals and brominated flame retardants as well as the application of the principle of making manufacturers responsible for the disposal of electrical and electronic waste. P The United States GPE delegation to the European Union ORG is concerned about certain points in the last consultation paper inter alia the phasing out of the materials already mentioned as well as certain questions arising from the principle of manufacturers responsibility for the disposal of electrical and electronic waste. The main argument put forward by the United States GPE in this context is that the present provisions are they say incompatible with international trade law. The Commission is currently carefully reviewing the United States GPE arguments. I should just like to add that my intention is that the Commission should be able to present a proposal on the dumping of electrical and electronic waste before Easter ORG . SPEAKER ID 198 CARDINAL NAME Lannoye My question specifically concerned the reaction of the US Government ORG to the text of the preliminary draft. There have in fact been three CARDINAL preliminary draft texts with the last one to my knowledge dating from July 1999 DATE . Is this the text which you will be submitting or an amendment to the original version? Version 3 CARDINAL is already much weaker than Version 2 LAW following the comments of US GPE industry as relayed by the US Government ORG . P I note in particular that when you talk about the international law with which the text would not be compatible you are referring in fact to the rules of the World Trade Organisation ORG . P The arguments of the US Government ORG concern the fact that a future ban on the presence of dangerous substances in electrical and electronic waste would be contrary to the WTO ORG rules. This worries me because this means that when adopting texts we are going to be continually threatened by attack from the World Trade Organisation ORG . This will fundamentally weaken European NORP environmental legislation and particularly this proposal. SPEAKER ID 199 LANGUAGE SV NAME Wallstr m Thank you for the follow up question. It is important for me to have a chance to answer it. It is clear that in a process such as this where we are discussing the disposal of a considerable stream of both electrical and electronic waste in Europe LOC there is an on going dialogue between the different parties concerned. The dialogue has been fruitful and has led to our preparing a proposal. Parts of it have been strengthened but other parts may well contain too many compromises. We are still in the process of preparing a text and the dialogue with the relevant parties will continue up until the last moment. P I do not think that the intervention of the United States GPE should push us in a direction that would lead to our taking insufficient account of environmental considerations. I strongly oppose using the WTO ORG and trade rules as a pretext for preventing the EU ORG from introducing radical environmental standards. I start from the assumption that we should in fact introduce these. However I do want to listen to all the points of view. For example I recently met representatives of the electronics industry who put forward suggestions including practical ones for improving our own proposal. However I totally reject any suggestion that I would allow the United States GPE to determine the shape of our directive. In fact I believe that we should be showing the way an intention that will also characterise the final proposal. SPEAKER ID 200 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 201 CARDINAL NAME Maj Britt Theorin Question No 42 CARDINAL by H 0026 00 ORG P Subject Gender PRODUCT and environment Practically PERSON all the contributors involved in the Rio ORG and Kyoto GPE processes individual organisations civic action groups governments the World Bank ORG the UN ORG and relief organisations believed that women should take a greater part in decision making on the environment. More women in decision making positions on various environmental bodies would extend the predominantly male terms of reference beyond business alone to embrace social justice as well. P Is the Commission prepared to adopt an action plan to increase the active participation of women in decision making in the environmental field? SPEAKER ID 202 LANGUAGE SV NAME Wallstr m In 1988 DATE the Commission introduced an action plan to promote equal opportunities for women and men. Through the current programme which covers the period 1997 to 2000 DATE we are endeavouring to encourage a workplace culture in which the value of both men and women is integrated and where gender specific needs are taken into consideration. One CARDINAL of the programme s aims is to develop and supervise methods strategies and measures for promoting gender equality in the decision making process and in positions of responsibility. Within the framework of the action plan each individual directorate general is to prepare its own programme of measures. One CARDINAL of the goals of those programmes is to increase the number of women in managerial positions. The new Commission ORG s own objective is to double the number of women managers before the end of its term of office. The same line is being pursued with particular vigour in the Directorate General for the Environment where nearly 60 per cent MONEY of directors and 20 per cent MONEY of unit heads are women. P Our policy is to encourage the recruitment of women to administrative posts in order to create a reserve of suitable candidates for future promotion to managerial positions. Currently women hold 24.5 per cent MONEY of our A grade posts and we hope the number will increase steadily. Moreover we are trying hard to attract qualified women to participate in our consultation groups. As regards our external partners all we can do is set them a good example and encourage their efforts to democratise their decision making processes. P With respect to the general principle of incorporating a perspective of equality as you know this principle is included in the Treaty of Amsterdam GPE . Article 3 of the Treaty LAW states that in all the activities referred to in this Article the Community LAW shall aim to eliminate inequalities and to promote equality between women and men. The Commission gives its full support to the efforts being made in this area and is continuing its investigations into whether specific measures can be implemented in the environmental field. I should of course like to take this opportunity to say that I appreciate the role played by the European Parliament s Committee ORG on Women s Rights and Equal Opportunities particularly its chair. SPEAKER ID 203 CARDINAL LANGUAGE SV NAME Theorin NORP I should just like to recall that during the lengthy process of approving the present Commission every Commissioner was questioned by the Women s Committee ORG on how they would tackle the issue of equality within their own particular field. We shall be monitoring each Commissioner carefully so the other Commissioners have now been forewarned. P Thank you for your reply. I interpret it as saying that you agree that what is needed is an action plan to enable more women to take part in specific environmental fields. I should also like to point out that the Beijing Declaration LAW emphasises the importance of having the institutional capacity to introduce a perspective of equality into all environmental programmes. Environmental agencies often do not have the required knowledge or procedures for incorporating such a perspective into their daily DATE work. I naturally want to know whether the Commissioner is willing to incorporate the idea of equality into environmental policy and programmes. This is a crucial goal. In order for all policies to be similarly permeated by the concept of equality it is especially important that people in key posts should have the basic knowledge required. SPEAKER ID 204 LANGUAGE SV NAME Wallstr m . SV My understanding of mainstreaming is of course that this should characterise everything we do. In the action plan prepared by my Directorate General issues of equality play a very important role. For example I am prepared to give seminars on leadership or other subjects myself to encourage women to take on further tasks within the Commission. If we are to be able to motivate everybody I believe it is extremely important for this message to be sent all the way from the top down or if you prefer from the bottom up. P My impression of environment related work broadly speaking is that in many instances it is dominated by women. This state of affairs must be encouraged so that women have a chance to secure managerial posts or reach high ranking positions in the environmental field. I should like to make it plain that our programme reflects that intention but there is certainly room for improvement. I have some experience in drawing up plans and following them up. I hope that this will be of benefit. SPEAKER ID 205 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 206 CARDINAL NAME Patricia McKenna Question PERSON No 43 by H 0045 00 DATE P Subject The Boyne Estuary WORK_OF_ART and the Drogheda Port Company The Boyne Estuary ORG is designated a Special Protection Area SPA under the Wild Birds Directive ORG and is under consideration for designation as a Special Area of Conservation under the Habitats Directive as it is an area of international importance. However the Department of the Marine Louth County Council ORG and Drogheda Corporation ORG have allowed the development of a new port in the SPA ORG and even the elimination of a mudflat at Stegrennan ORG recently added to the SPA ORG specifically at the Commission ORG s insistence. What is more a very large warehouse has been constructed in respect of which it is proving difficult to secure access to the planning permission and other infrastructures are planned by the Drogheda Corporation ORG . How can the Commission ensure that this sort of development financed through the Structural Funds ORG does not conflict with the nature conservation needs of the area? Is the Commission ready to suspend funding completely pending a review of the development plans of the area? SPEAKER ID 207 LANGUAGE SV NAME Wallstr m The Commission is aware of the construction of the harbour but we know nothing about the warehouse or the rest of the infrastructure mentioned by the honourable Member. The harbour construction project is receiving support from the Structural Funds and chiefly involves dredging the river Boyne Estuary PERSON and depositing the mud on the mudflats at Stegrennan ORG . P The Boyne Estuary is designated a special protection area under the Wild Birds Directive ORG . That means that any development that takes place in or near the Boyne Estuary FAC and that is likely to affect the special protection area must take account of the protection criteria for the area laid down in the Community s Habitats Directive PERSON . P Since 1998 DATE the Commission has received a number of complaints alleging that the harbour will damage the mudflats at Stegrennan which are now designated a part of the special protection area and that the relevant protection criteria have not been observed. P After investigating these complaints between 1998 and the beginning of 1999 DATE during which time the project did not receive support from the Structural Funds the Commission ORG became convinced in the summer of 1999 DATE that the relevant protection criteria had been observed during the building of the harbour. An in depth environmental impact assessment had been carried out. The most serious harm caused by the project the damage to the Stegrennan ORG mudflats was only to be temporary and the developers were liable for completely restoring the mudflats. P At the Commission ORG s suggestion the mudflats at Stegrennan were formally included in the Boyne Estuary special protection area from which they had previously been excluded. Furthermore to compensate for the negative effects on the bird populations caused by the temporary disappearance of the mudflats the intention was that other habitats in the estuary should be improved. P However since last summer DATE the measure just mentioned has been in dispute. Firstly ORDINAL the Irish NORP authorities withdrew their earlier commitment to carry out improvements. They then renewed their commitment after an Irish NORP non governmental organisation began a legal challenge in the Irish NORP courts. However the new commitment included some minor changes which in turn led to a further complaint. In view of the fact that the Irish NORP authorities have undertaken to make compensatory improvements and that other issues have already been resolved the Commission will not for the present propose that financial support from the Structural Funds should be suspended. However it wishes to discuss the question of compensatory measures with respect to improved habitats with the Irish NORP authorities particularly in the light of the continuing legal challenge in the Irish NORP courts. SPEAKER ID 208 CARDINAL NAME McKenna PERSON I do not quite understand what the Commissioner said. The mudflat at Stregrennan PERSON which was made a special protection area at the request of the Commission ORG has been completely destroyed at this stage. It is clear that the activities that have taken place there are in clear breach of EU ORG directives. P You say there will be no further funding. I would like to know whether you are going to stop completely the funding at this stage until there is a proper investigation. If not why not? If you are when exactly are you going to do it? Is it correct and proper that the department which owns the company is also the authority which issues the licence and also the authority which basically takes the money from the EU ORG and gives it to a company that it owns 100 CARDINAL ? Is this right and proper? What is your opinion on that? Any EU ORG funding for the project must be stopped because it is in clear breach of EU ORG directives. Even the area designated by the Commissioners as a special protection area has been destroyed. Compensation afterwards is not going to make up for the damage that was done. SPEAKER ID 209 CARDINAL NAME Wallstr m The first ORDINAL legal challenge followed the start of work on the port of development in early autumn 1999 DATE without the compensatory habitat improvements being in place. As a result the Irish NORP authorities agreed to reinstate the cord grass removal but this time by direct mechanical means. The use of mechanical means led to a further legal challenge that is what I referred to also in my first ORDINAL answer based on the argument that mechanical removal would damage the underlying mudflats and would cause the ecologically harmful spread of cord grass in the estuary. There is to date no conclusive outcome to this legal challenge. P The adoption of the necessary compensatory measures is a matter for the national authorities and does not require prior Commission ORG approval. The Commission ORG s role is to make sure that the standards required by the Birds Directive ORG are fully met and clearly there would be a problem with compensatory measures which were themselves damaging. In this case the Commission proposes to seek further clarification from the Irish NORP authorities on the up to date position on the compensatory measures and possible problems with the mechanical removal of cord grass. We are not at the moment ready to propose to stop the financing from the Structural Funds. SPEAKER ID 210 PRODUCT NAME Martin David W Mr PERSON President sadly the specific case raised by Mrs McKenna PERSON is not an isolated one. There are other examples of conservation in special scientific areas being damaged as a result of EU ORG funding. It is only such action which will discourage this practice in the future. SPEAKER ID 211 CARDINAL LANGUAGE SV NAME Wallstr m . SV This is a very important question. As MEPs are well aware in the course of last year DATE a joint text was issued by our predecessors in the Commission Ritt Bjerregaard PERSON and Monika Wulf Mathies PERSON concerning the relationship between the Structural Funds money from the Structural Funds and protection under the Habitats PERSON and Birds Directives. The message contained in the joint text is still valid. We cannot hand out money with one hand and with the other take countries to court where they may well be fined. It is therefore important that there be a coordination strategy. The result may of course be some difficult questions of priorities. In my view the most important consequence however is that countries should do some careful thinking and above all make sure they send in their lists of Natura 2000 ORG sites. Then we will be in a position to carry out methodical monitoring and follow up procedures. In that respect Ireland GPE falls short like other Member States but we hope that the pressure we are exerting will produce results. P I should just like to point out once again that the joint text still holds good. SPEAKER ID 212 NAME President The Rules of Procedure do not allow this. You will have to discuss this outside the Chamber ORG . SPEAKER ID 220 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 221 CARDINAL NAME Marie Anne Isler PERSON B guin Question No 45 CARDINAL by H 0041 00 ORG P Subject Structural Fund ORG financing of research in the civil nuclear technology field Can the Commission ORG confirm that in the last Structural Fund ORG programming period 1994 DATE 1999 DATE no assistance was granted to research in the nuclear fusion or fission areas? Will the Structural Funds also finance the large scale energy transmission networks? SPEAKER ID 222 CARDINAL NAME Barnier On Mrs Isler B guin s first ORDINAL point I must remind her that the improvement of the scientific basis and technical capacities of the regions in order to increase their competitiveness was one of the Community ORG s priorities during the previous programming period. P The support allocated by the Structural Funds ORG for technological cohesion or research and technical developments within the Community ORG support frameworks for that period is estimated at approximately EUR 7.5 billion MONEY . This is about 6 CARDINAL of the whole Community contribution. P With regard to your specific concern I can say that as in the previous period DATE the Commission does not intend to directly finance through the Structural Funds ORG research and technical development in the area of nuclear fusion or fission. However it is still the responsibility of the Member States management authorities to select the projects to be implemented within these CSFs. P Consequently even though this is not a Community ORG priority a Member State can decide to finance research and development projects in the civil nuclear technology area provided that these projects contribute to regional development. The Commission ORG does not have to be systematically informed of these. P On your second ORDINAL point of renewable energy which as you know is of great interest to me the Commission s approach is given in the document on the Structural Funds and their coordination with the Cohesion Funds. These Funds specify that investments in the renewable energy sector must be encouraged where they favour the development of local resources where they contribute to reducing dependency on energy imports and where they create jobs at local level. P I was able to verify this for example during a visit I made to the Azores in Portugal GPE a few days ago DATE with regard to a natural source of renewable energy. The Structural Funds contribution which has enabled greater penetration of the renewable energy market was also underlined in the campaign to promote renewable energy sources launched by the Transport and Energy Department ORG . P Finally on large scale energy transmission networks the guidelines also provide for financial participation from the Funds to develop these networks where this helps to reduce dependency on an external supplier or to combat the effects of isolation. This is particularly valid for the region of the Azores which I have just mentioned and also for all most remote regions. It is also valid for certain regions handicapped by their isolation due to mountains for example. SPEAKER ID 223 CARDINAL LANGUAGE FR NAME Isler B PERSON guin Commissioner thank you for your answer. However I asked this question because we are rightly concerned that the report on the third ORDINAL framework programme for research contains a project entitled International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor FAC . P You did not fully answer the last part of my question on large scale energy transmission networks. Could you please give an answer on this issue? SPEAKER ID 224 CARDINAL LANGUAGE FR NAME Barnier You are concerned about whether the Structural Funds ORG will be used to finance the installation of nuclear plants anywhere. Quite simply there is no question of this. I said that the selection of projects remains the responsibility of the Member States pursuant to the Structural Funds Regulation ORG . As a result the Commission services are not systematically informed of all projects selected. However you are right to question me as this is your task as mine is to answer you. I will therefore step beyond the confidence usually shared between Member States and the Commission and I will find out exactly what is happening on this specific point. The Member State or States GPE concerned will then be required to answer me and I will send you this answer as soon as possible. P I thought I had answered your question on large scale energy transmission networks. The energy situation varies widely from region to region in the European Union ORG . Assistance from the Structural Funds could be justified in certain cases and for certain regions particularly in the case where the connection to basic energy networks is still underdeveloped. This is the only answer I can give you on the link between large scale energy transmission networks and the Structural Funds ORG . SPEAKER ID 225 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 226 CARDINAL NAME Neil MacCormick Question No 46 by H 0052 00 ORG P Subject Structural Funds and additionality In the light of the Commission ORG s recent helpful response to my priority Written Question about Structural Funds and additionality I wish to ask whether the Commission ORG has any plans to seek amendment of the rules concerning additionality. In particular would the Commission look favourably on a change in the rules to ensure that additionality operates not only at the level of Member States but also within Member States with regard to budgetary provisions between central government and internally autonomous regions or countries? SPEAKER ID 227 CARDINAL NAME Barnier Mr MacCormick the Commission PERSON has no plans to amend the rules concerning additionality which were stipulated for the 2000 2006 period in Article 11 LAW of the general Regulation on the Funds. As in the past these rules state that the additionality principle applies to the relationship between the Structural Funds and all development expenditure of the Member State. P In this respect it must be stressed that it is the expenditure financed by the Structural Funds ORG which must be additional. The cofinancing provided by the Member State does not need to be additional to its existing expenditure. Provided that the Member State does not reduce all its own expenditure the Structural Funds are added to the national expenditure and the principle of additionality is therefore respected. P As for the budgetary provisions within the Member States between central government and internal autonomous regions or countries these are determined according to exclusively national considerations and are therefore not affected by additionality within the meaning defined in the rules. Please excuse this very legal answer. However after verification it is precisely in this legal manner and specifically according to the post Berlin Structural Funds Regulation that we must define and read the additionality principle. SPEAKER ID 228 CARDINAL NAME MacCormick I am grateful for a clear answer though naturally a little disappointed by its content. We are left with Article 11 1 LAW which says that the appropriations of the funds may not replace public or other equivalent structural expenditure by the Member States GPE . Very well that is to be the unchanging rule. Does section 11 1 LAW conceivably authorise the following practice. When an autonomous region s or country s funding from European NORP structural funds increases the state makes a concomitant reduction in central funding to that region so that the total funding package available matches a formula set nationally without regard to the quantum of structural funds granted by the Union. Is that really authorised? SPEAKER ID 229 CARDINAL NAME Barnier Unfortunately I do not have time to go into depth on this issue. If Mr MacCormick would be satisfied with my partial agreement with his reasoning I will give him a full answer in writing by restating the legal bases of both Article 11 LAW in general and Article 11 1 LAW in particular. I am aware of the Member s competence on these matters. I also know the particular problems in your constituency in Scotland GPE where disputes and discussions are occurring on these subjects. P However on a general level I would say that in all cases it is the Structural Funds expenditure which must be additional. This is how provided that the Member State does not reduce all its own expenditure the Structural Funds can be added to the national expenditure and we can consider that the additionality principle is respected. P I will go further in the written answer which I have promised in order to set things out more objectively and precisely. SPEAKER ID 230 CARDINAL NAME Evans Jillian Additionality PERSON is a major issue too in Wales GPE which I represent. Just last week DATE it was one of the issues that brought about a vote of no confidence and the resignation of the First ORDINAL Secretary of the National Assembly of Wales ORG . P As recently as 1991 DATE and 1992 the Commission won a battle with the UK GPE over additionality at that time linked to the RECHAR ORG funding. This led to an agreement being signed whereby the UK Government ORG agreed to introduce procedures to ensure that EU ORG spending reached the areas for which is was intended and was actually additional. And yet we still have these problems in Wales GPE and in Scotland GPE . P Could the Commission look at this particular situation in relation to the agreement that was signed with the UK Government ORG ? SPEAKER ID 241 CARDINAL NAME President SPEAKER ID 242 CARDINAL NAME Luis Berenguer PERSON Fuster Question No 51 by H 0049 00 P Subject New premises for the OHIM ORG At present the Office for Harmonisation in ORG the Internal Market OHIM ORG is still operating from the same temporary premises even though its new building was opened in June 1999 DATE . P In view of this unusual situation will the Commission say why the OHIM ORG has not yet moved to its new premises? SPEAKER ID 243 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL ORG NAME Bolkestein PERSON The honourable Member asked a question on this topic in November 1999 DATE and I would like to refer him to the answer given at the time. Furthermore I have asked the president of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market ORG that is to say the Office in Alicante to comment further on this new question and I can as a result inform the honourable Member as follows on behalf of the Office P ORG The Office is not yet ready to move into the new building. Unfortunately a number of deadlines have been exceeded. A number of technical provisions need to be made such as the installation of a computer network archives a canteen and furniture. The OHIM ORG is now in the process of arranging this and is expecting to move into the new premises by June DATE . SPEAKER ID 244 CARDINAL LANGUAGE ES NAME Berenguer Fuster During the previous question we were discussing electoral issues. I believe that this issue is relevant to my question. Commissioner you were not present at the extraordinarily named official opening of the headquarters of the OHIM ORG on 9 June DATE in the middle of an election campaign in Spain GPE leading up to both the European NORP elections and the local and regional elections. P If you had been there I am sure you would have been ashamed. The President of the Commission and some secretaries were present. In the middle of an election campaign a series of authorities all of them run by the party in government made clearly electioneering speeches which furthermore were broadcast live on television. It was bizarre to see the President of the Region of Valencia praising the work of the Spanish Government ORG as well as his own work although it was irrelevant to that event. P The opening of a building which was not finished in the middle of an election campaign which eight months DATE after the opening can still not be occupied makes the Spanish Government look ridiculous. I am not worried that the Spanish Government ORG should look foolish because at the end of the day DATE it was their responsibility but it does worry me that the Commission should look foolish by endorsing through its presence this absurd event. P I would therefore like to ask you Mr Commissioner does it seem normal to you that an unfinished building should be opened during an election campaign? Does it seem normal to you that the Commission should attend such an absurd event organised by the Spanish Government ORG ? SPEAKER ID 245 LANGUAGE NL NAME Bolkestein PERSON It does not fall within my remit to make statements about internal political situations within one CARDINAL Member State or another. As such I would prefer to withhold any comment on the situation which Mr Berenguer NORP has just described. I have to confess that I fail to comprehend why a certain opening ceremony was held in Spain GPE . What I can say is that I hope that this building will now be occupied as soon as possible. May I also add that I hope to be in Alicante myself at the end of May to speak at a conference. I hope that this building will then be occupied. SPEAKER ID 246 CARDINAL LANGUAGE ES NAME Medina Ortega PERSON I would like to point out to the Commissioner that it is not an electoral question. As members of the Committee on Legal Affairs ORG and the Internal Market ORG we have followed the creation of that institution and it is clear that it was established for electioneering reasons. A year later DATE it is still not functioning which means that the Commission ORG spent money on a false opening. We should ask ourselves to what extent this spending of funds was justified. SPEAKER ID 247 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL ORG NAME Bolkestein PERSON I would like to reiterate that the Commission is unconcerned with the underlying motivation of Member State actions. It is however interested in official statements and actions. We do not intend to go in the direction of what is termed in French NORP un proc s d intention. We are concerned with public official actions and events rather than any possible underlying motivation. This is why I find it also difficult to meet Mr Medina LOC halfway and respond to his question. Once again the Commission does not speculate why something is happening earlier or later than planned. It only appreciates that a building for this Office is opened and occupied as soon as possible. P Also the Commission does not engage itself in finding out whether certain expenditure was real or virtual. As far as I am concerned all expenditure is real. And any remaining skeletons I intend to leave them in the cupboard. SPEAKER ID 248 CARDINAL NAME President As the author is not present Question No 52 lapses. P As they deal with the same subject Questions Nos PERSON 53 and 54 will be taken together. SPEAKER ID 249 CARDINAL NAME Jan Andersson Question No 53 by H 0057 00 P Subject Swedish NORP derogation regarding the import of alcoholic beverages At present Sweden GPE has a derogation until 2004 DATE allowing restrictions on alcoholic beverage imports. The Swedish Government ORG and a large percentage of the Swedish NORP people want the derogation to be extended on public health grounds. P What is the Commission ORG s position on the Swedish NORP derogation concerning these imports? SPEAKER ID 250 CARDINAL NAME Bernd Posselt Question No 54 by H 0117 00 ORG P Subject Alcohol ORG monopoly and the internal market What action does the Commission ORG intend to take in order to prevent the extension of the State ORG alcohol monopoly apparently being planned by Sweden GPE and the associated import restrictions and to ensure that the rules of the single market are applied? SPEAKER ID 251 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL NAME Bolkestein PERSON I would like to answer these two CARDINAL questions as follows. When Sweden GPE joined the European Union ORG it was allowed to retain quantitative restrictions on alcoholic beverages which travellers can bring into the country from other Member States. This derogation from the principle of the free movement of goods lapses on 30 June of this year DATE . Sweden GPE now wants to extend this measure by another five years DATE as this would be necessary to protect public health. My position on this is clear. Sweden GPE has now had sufficient time since its accession to the Union to adapt its policies to a situation where such import restrictions do not exist. I cannot see a reason therefore why a further extension for this measure should be proposed. European NORP citizens have the right to buy goods for their own use including taxes in any Member Sate and to take them to another Member Sate without having to subject these goods to controls and without possibly having to pay another set of taxes on them. That is a basic principle governing the internal market and derogations from this principle must be exceptions and must be limited in time. P We want to guarantee that Swedish NORP citizens too can enjoy the benefits of the internal market just like other citizens of the European Union ORG . This certainly does not mean that I do not share the concern in Sweden GPE surrounding the possible health problems which can be caused by alcohol abuse. A recent study carried out by Professor Lindgren PERSON of the University of Lund ORG however has shown that abolishing the restrictions would not lead to a higher alcohol consumption in Sweden GPE . P I have already had a chance to discuss my position with Mr Ringholm the Swedish NORP Finance Minister on two CARDINAL occasions. I also discussed this matter with the Swedish NORP parliamentary Finance ORG committee last week DATE . It is now up to the Swedish NORP government to take the necessary measures. SPEAKER ID 252 CARDINAL LANGUAGE SV NAME Andersson Thank you for your reply. I should just like to apologise for the error in my question to the Commission. Instead of 2004 DATE it should of course be 1 July 2000 DATE . P I have some sympathy with the Commission ORG s standpoint that derogations should only be granted occasionally. Such a rule is only normal. Nevertheless I should like to ask two CARDINAL questions Are you thinking of embarking upon continued discussions with the Swedish NORP Government about extending the derogations for example for as long as Denmark GPE and Finland GPE have derogations? P My second ORDINAL question concerns the whole policy on alcohol. This may of course be seen as an issue concerning the internal market but also as a public health matter for the whole EU ORG . What are the respective roles of alcohol policy and public health considerations in the Commission ORG s work? A Europe LOC wide policy on alcohol is not just an issue concerning the internal market. It also has important implications for public health. If we had considered these aspects in their overall context then it might have been easier to carry on a dialogue with Sweden GPE . SPEAKER ID 253 LANGUAGE NL PERSON NAME Bolkestein PERSON May I thank Mr Andersson for the supplement to his first ORDINAL question and may I answer that question as follows? P Firstly Finland and Denmark GPE are subject to exemptions to the basic rule of the free movement of goods until 2003 DATE . These countries are in the process of taking measures in preparation of free access of alcoholic products in the year 2003 DATE . P However in the case of Sweden GPE the situation is different. In 1995 DATE a five year DATE derogation period was decided upon which is now lapsing. I have as yet not heard any arguments on the basis of which the Commission would need to extend this period. P Secondly the Swedish NORP Government is being consulted all the way. I can inform Mr Andersson that I will leave for Stockholm GPE on Monday 6 March DATE in order to talk to Minister Ringholm PERSON to members of the Swedish NORP parliament and if necessary also to the Prime Minister or other ministers in order to continue discussions on this matter. I am fully aware that emotions are running high in the political arena in Sweden GPE regarding this issue. P Thirdly ORDINAL I understand very well that the health aspect of this matter is naturally important. I would repeat at this juncture what Professor Lindgren PERSON of Lund University ORG has stated namely that whatever happens in terms of import restrictions the consumption of alcohol will remain the same. The question is then of course where does the volume of alcohol originate from which is not imported by travellers? The answer is that this is smuggled into the country or made by the Swedes NORP themselves and as Mr Andersson knows this is an extremely dangerous and unhealthy activity. P Well now Mr Andersson seems to think that the health situation will improve if we restrict the import of alcohol. But in that case not only Sweden GPE but all EU ORG countries should then be subject to a total ban on alcohol. We can cast our minds back to a similar situation in the United States GPE . Mr Andersson will be familiar with what was termed then prohibition . He will also be aware of the effects the ban had on Mafia ORG activity within the United States GPE where eventually prohibition was withdrawn. All this means that we need to protect health of course but not by banning alcohol because that does not work. SPEAKER ID 254 LANGUAGE DE NAME Posselt Mr President the question at issue is the income from the Swedish NORP alcohol monopoly and when the Swedish Government ORG says that it must cover health costs then this is proof of a distortion of competition because other countries must cover their health costs themselves with no alcohol monopoly at their disposal. My question refers to whether you too know of studies which state that a moderate intake of good quality alcohol such as Franconian wine or Bavarian NORP beer is good for you and would therefore also be good for the Swedish NORP budget. SPEAKER ID 255 CARDINAL LANGUAGE NL ORG NAME Bolkestein PERSON I gather that Mr Posselt has hinted at the fiscal aspects of this matter. I also happen to know that the high tax on alcohol products in Sweden GPE goes back to the year 1638 DATE and that since then the sale of alcohol products has accounted for a significant portion of the state s tax revenue. As is known this has led to a state monopoly in Sweden GPE which in itself is at odds with Union legislation. P As to the healing effect of alcohol to which I believe Mr Posselt also made reference I could not agree more with him I think that a good bottle of wine can be extremely good for your health and is also socially extremely pleasant and perhaps Mr Posselt Mr Andersson and myself could meet in the bar of this Parliament ORG one of these days to share an aquavit. Can we now expect the European Commission ORG to take action against the French Republic GPE before the European Court of Justice ORG ? The Commission ORG has to take a decision on whether the matter is closed or whether it should refer it to the European Court of Justice ORG .
